major_name: Computational Mathematics (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Introduction to Mathematical Biology Winter 2025
Email: cbauch@uwaterloo.ca
Email: TBD
Students develop an intuition for describing the biological world in mathematical terms, by writing down and analyzing mathematical models of biological systems.
Students also collaborate in team projects where they are required to construct, analyze and interpret models using mathematical software packages, and present their work to the class.
Biology prerequisites are not necessary, but knowledge of differential equations and matrix algebra is required.

Sampling of material offered: ecology (exponential growth models, logistic growth models, predator-prey dynamics, competition models); epidemiology (compartmental models of childhood infectious diseases, influenza); microbiology (slime mold growth; cell cycles); population genetics; and physiology.

Techniques learned will include stability analysis of discrete-time models and ordinary differential equations, phase plane methods and qualitative solutions, travelling wave solutions of partial differential equations, and use of mathematical software for modelling.
In some populations, dynamics can be broken down into discrete stages (for instance, insects that reproduce only during a particular time of year).
In these cases, difference equations that describe time is a discrete way are appropriate models.
We will discuss the theory of linear and nonlinear difference equations and their applications in biology.
We will introduce the topic of ordinary differential equation models and their formulation and analysis in the context of biological problems.

In both parts I and II, we will emphasise how appropriate assumptions can simplify the biological problem, how important variables can be identified and how difference/differential equations can be tailored to describe the essential features of a biological process.
After defining the problem and formulating a consistent set of equations, we will turn to the analysis of their solutions.
Introduction to Spatially Distributed Systems, Partial Differential Equations and Other Methodologies.
In order to analyze them it is necessary to develop models that capture spatial structure of real populations.
Partial differential equations can provide means for modeling spatially structured biological processes.
We will briefly introduce these methodologies and demonstrate how they can be applied to study spatio-temporal dynamics of biological phenomena.

course_name: CO485 - The Mathematics of Public-Key Cryptography (0.50)
major_name: Computational Mathematics (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: The Mathematics of Public-Key Cryptography Fall 2024
An in-depth study of public-key cryptography.
Public-key encryption, digital signatures, key establishment, elliptic curve cryptography, post-quantum cryptography.

An in-depth study of public-key cryptography, including: number-theoretic problems - prime generation, integer factorization, discrete logarithms; public-key encryption; digital signatures; key establishment; elliptic curve cryptography; post-quantum cryptography; and security proofs.
An in-depth study of public-key cryptography and number-theoretic problems related to the efficient and secure use of public-key cryptographic schemes.
Algorithmic number theory: Primality testing, integer factorization problem, discrete logarithm problem, elliptic curve discrete logarithm problem.
Additional topics: Pairing-based cryptography, post-quantum cryptography.
An Introduction to Mathematical Cryptography (2nd ed.), Hoffstein, Pipher, and Silverman.

course_name: COMMST192 - Communication in the Engineering Profession (COMPE, ELE, MGTE) (0.50)
major_name: Computer Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: D. Shakespeare
In this course students in Computer, Electrical, and Management Engineering will enhance oral and written communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession.

By participating in classes and completing course assignments, you will practice genres of communication crafted for audiences that might include employers, clients, peer groups, technical staff, public audiences, and regulatory and policy-focused stakeholders.
By focusing on genre, design, and audience, you will come to better understand concepts including meaning-making, perception, and responsibility.
More generally, in this course, students can and should learn professional norms of technical communication and dominant forms of sharing knowledge within the fields of engineering.
Yet this course also attempts to teach students how these communicative forms are matters of social context and sites of negotiation and contestation.
We also hope students will find their place and voice in the conversations in their fields of study and reflect on the meaning and shape of available forums for technical communication.
describe and apply conventions, genres, and norms, and values of communication in an engineering discipline
compose persuasive, audience-specific technical arguments
analyze and summarize technical content in a clear and concise way
You (students) will understand the complexity of communication as a human process of shared meaning-making in the context of power, history, and culture.

You will increase your capacity to recognize and enhance yours and others’ agency – the ability to make a difference in the world for yourself and others – and understand the implications of your communication behaviours for yourself and others.
You will recognize diverse linguistic practices and modes of communication as resources for writers and speakers.

You will understand communication as a practice, and improve your critical and creative communication competencies by developing your ability to use writing, speaking, and other media of communication to create effective and engaging artifacts.

You will reflect on your role in fostering the public good (the multifaceted well-being of individuals and groups), begin to imagine a better future, and make decisions in your communication that can transform the communities to which you belong.

topics: Songmin Xu s83xu@uwaterloo.ca
Mastering Physics technical support: https://support.pearson.com/getsupport/s/
This is a fast-paced survey course (covering about one textbook chapter per week) introducing a wide range of topics in modern physics.

The intention is four-fold: (1) to make first-year physics more interesting; (2) to provide important, intuitive understanding of key modern physics concepts before your more mathematically rigorous courses in second year; (3) to help you decide which areas of physics you may wish to explore in more depth in upper-year electives; and (4) to have at least a brief introduction to important branches of physics you may not explore further in your degree.
Apply Newton's second law and Newton's law of universal gravitation to solve basic problems in gravitational physics.
Understand, distinguish between and correctly use the concepts of weight, weightlessness, and apparent weight.
Solve simple problems in orbital motion and apply Kepler's three laws.

Properly understand Einstein's two postulates and logically derive from them, and apply, the concepts of time dilation, length contraction, Doppler shift, velocity composition, relativity of simultaneity, and understand why special relativity works for both wave-in-ether and particle-in-vacuum models of light..
Articulate the basic, intuitive ideas of how Einstein's geometrical model of gravity works (equivalence principle and curved spacetime).
Appreciate that classical physics cannot explain the single or double slit experiments.
Understand and predict basic properties of the quantum hydrogen atom based on only the de Broglie relation and classical properties of electron orbits.
Understand the basic idea of a complex number, and in particular, a complex exponential wave, and use it to "derive" the Schrodinger equation.
Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate ionic bonds, covalent bonds, van der Waals bonds, and basic molecular spectra.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate the basic features of atomic nuclei, including nuclear binding energy, nuclear models, nuclear stability and radioactivity, nuclear reactions, nuclear fission, and nuclear fusion.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate some basic aspects of collider physics, including the concept of available energy, and an introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics.
Feb 24 Wave Functions Wave Functions
Mar 17 Nuclear Nuclear

ECE 750 / ECE 493
kerstin.dautenhahn@uwaterloo.ca
Prof. Kerstin Dautenhahn:
kerstin.dautenhahn@uwaterloo.ca
ECE 750:
View requirements for ECE 750
View requirements for ECE 493
The course will provide an introduction to the research field of social robotics, with a particular human-centered perspective.

Robots that can interact socially in an effective and acceptable manner with people have become increasingly important for applications ranging from robot-assisted therapy for people with special needs, robotic assistants for older people and care home residents, robots as tools in education or robotic co-workers for a new generation of  industrial robot that emphasize human-machine collaboration and communication.

Students will gain an understanding of the concepts and theories underlying social robotics, as well as research methodologies and techniques to realize socially intelligent robots and design, plan and evaluate human-robot interaction experiments.
Understand concepts and theories underlying social robotics
Apply research methodologies and techniques to realize socially intelligent robots
Design, plan, and evaluate human-robot interaction experiments
Demonstrate scientific writing and presentation skills
Explain how psychology and social sciences can inform the engineering of social robots
Understand basic principles of sensors, actuators and multi-model interaction and communication for social robots
Explain examples of robot computational architectures used in human-robot interaction
Definitions of social robots and requirements of robots’ social skill and their relevance to robotics and Artificial Intelligence in real-world applications
The role of affective expressions of social robots and modelling emotions to facilitate human-robot engagement
Evaluating usability, user experience and acceptance of social robots
Guidelines of how to write up social robotics research for a scientific publication
Overview of cognitive architectures for socially intelligent robots
Featuring interdisciplinary research in social robotics based on research from other fields, e.g. from (developmental) psychology, ethology or primatology
Roles of social robots in human society and their potential impact on society and wellbeing
Selected examples of applications of social robots e.g. in care, therapy, education, rehabilitation and co-worker scenarios will be discussed throughout the course
Ethical, safety and privacy issues as relevant to social robotics will be discussed throughout the course
Course Grading for Graduate Students:

20% Individual discussion paper: Students will reflect on work in Science Fiction involving the concepts of social and intelligent robots, and reflect on the relevance to today’s robotics technology in robotics and Artificial Intelligence.
Students can choose the work and discuss the selection with the instructor.

Students are required to write a report that motivates, describes and discusses those behaviours in light of the state of the art literature, and describe an experimental design for a human-robot interaction experiment where those behaviours could be tested and analyzed.

Specifically, students’ reports will be evaluated based on a) the literature review demonstrating the level of knowledge in this domain, b) the relevance of the identified research questions and hypotheses, c) the depth of the proposed research program, d) the range, complexity and quality of the implemented and documented robot behaviours, e) the detailed description of the methodology used to carry out and analyze this program of work, f) the user study conducted and how results are presented and analysed, and finally, g) a critical evaluation of possible limitations of the expected outcomes and backup plans in order to address  possible delays and technical difficulties encountered during the implementation of the work.
Note, those skills can also be applied to related fields of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI), Human Factors etc.

20% Individual discussion paper: Students will reflect on work in Science Fiction involving the concepts of social and intelligent robots, and reflect on the relevance to today’s robotics technology in robotics and Artificial Intelligence.
Students can choose the work and discuss the selection with the instructor.

Students are required to write a report that motivates, describes and discusses those behaviours in light of the state of the art literature, and describe a possible experimental design for a human-robot interaction experiment where those implemented behaviours could be tested and analyzed.

Specifically, students’ reports will be evaluated based on a) the literature review demonstrating the level of knowledge in this domain, b) the relevance of the identified research questions and hypotheses, c) the depth of the proposed research program, d) the range, complexity and quality of the implemented and documented robot behaviours, e) the detailed description of the methodology used to carry out and analyze this program of work, f) a critical evaluation of possible limitations of the expected outcomes and backup plans in order to address  possible delays and technical difficulties encountered during the implementation of the work.
Note, those skills can also be applied to related fields of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI), Human Factors etc.

major_name: Business Administration and Computer Science Double Degree (Bachelor of Business Administration and Bachelor of Computer Science - Honours)
topics: Linear Algebra 1 (Advanced Level)
Email: karigiannis@uwaterloo.ca
This course is a rigorous treatment of the theory of finite dimensional vector spaces over an arbitrary field.
We also cover the theory of determinants over an arbitrary commutative ring with identity, and some aspects of the theory of polynomials in one variable over a field.

The ultimate goal is the Primary Decomposition Theorem, which characterizes a linear operator on a finite dimensional vector space in terms of invariant subspaces annihilated by the primary factors of its minimal polynomial.
We will cover a large amount of difficult material at a fast pace.
Understand and apply the concepts of the theory of abstract vector spaces and linear operators on finite-dimensional vector spaces.
fields; systems of linear equations; matrices; row-reduced echelon form; matrix algebra; invertible matrices
vector spaces; subspaces; bases and dimension; coordinates; row equivalence
algebra of linear maps; isomorphism; representations by matrices; dual space; transpose of a linear map
commutative rings; existence and uniqueness of determinants; multilinear maps; the exterior algebra
eigenvalues; annihilating polynomials; invariant subspaces; simultaneous triangulation and diagonalization
Much (but not all) of my lectures will closely follow the first six chapters of this book:
“Linear Algebra: Second Edition” by Kenneth Hoffman and Ray Kunze; Prentice Hall, 1971.
“Linear Algebra: Fourth Edition” by Friedberg, Insel, and Spence; Prentice-Hall, 2003.
The assignments are an integral part of your evaluation in this course and I encourage everyone to take them very seriously.
There will be no opportunity for a make-up midterm test.

major_name: Computer Science (Bachelor of Computer Science - Honours)
topics: Introduction to Computer Science 1 Winter 2025
Diren Swayze
An introduction to the fundamentals of computer science through the application of elementary programming patterns in the functional style of programming.
As we are aware of the varied ways in which this material might be of use in the future, we have included concepts that are beautiful and universal.

Because of the fundamental nature of the concepts taught in CS 115, the course can serve both students whose primary interest in computers is in their use in their chosen areas of study and students intending to minor in CS.
Module 01: Introduction Monday January 6
Module 03: Strings and Symbols Monday January 13
Module 06: Structural Recursion Monday February 3
Module 08: Local Evaluation Monday February 24
Module 09: Higher-Order Functions Monday March 3

major_name: Computer Science (Bachelor of Computer Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Computer Organization and Design Winter 2025
RCH 307
Silvia Zhang cs251@uwaterloo.ca
Basics of digital logic design.
Data representation and manipulation.
Basics of processor design.

This course enables students to develop an accurate mental model of the architecture and organization of physical computers and it introduces them to theoretical and practical concepts relevant to the structure and design of modern digital computers.

Design simple combinational and sequential hardware at the logic gate level in order to implement simple algorithms and computations, such as addition, multiplication, and data-path control for processors.
Describe number systems used by computer hardware, including IEEE floating point and two's complement.
Analyze how machine language is executed by hardware, and describe a simple pipelined processor architecture for executing a RISC machine language.
Explain basic cache and virtual-memory architectures, and how they can impact performance.
Introduction and ARM (~3 hours)
Combinational logic and basic components.
Basic Processor Design (~9 hours)
Processor design using single-cycle control.
Multi-cycle control.
Virtual memory.
Multi-processor systems and core processors.
Patterson and Hennessy: "Computer Organization and Design".
Students registering their clicker for other sections will receive a grade of zero on clicker questions.

topics: Notice of Recording
E. Bembenek
cpthowel@uwaterloo.ca
E. Yalcin
Introduction to the Riemann integral and approximations.
Antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus.
Applications of the integral.
Improper integrals.
Linear and separable differential equations and applications.
Binomial series, functions defined as power series and Taylor series.
The goal of this course is to further expand your knowledge of calculus and its applications for one-variable functions.

First, we will explore areas under curves and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, integration techniques, and applications of integration including finding the area between two curves, volumes of solids of revolution, and the average value of a function.
We will study how to solve separable differential equations and linear differential equations as well as their applications to population growth and Newton's Law of Cooling.
Write clear and well-organized mathematical solutions and proofs.
Solve problems in Calculus through logical thinking and careful analysis.
Set up and evaluate Riemann integrals for simple functions
Apply various integration techniques including change of variable, integration by parts, trigonometric substitution, and partial fractions.
Solve separable and first-order linear differential equations.
Compute the radius and interval of convergence for power series.
Compute Taylor Polynomials and Taylor series for many elementary functions.

The goal of this course is to further expand your knowledge of calculus and its applications for one-variable functions.

First, we will explore areas under curves and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, integration techniques, and applications of integration including finding the area between two curves, volumes of solids of revolution, and the average value of a function.
We will study how to solve separable differential equations and linear differential equations as well as their applications to population growth and Newton's Law of Cooling.
Write clear and well-organized mathematical solutions and proofs.

Solve separable and first-order linear differential equations.

major_name: Computer Science (Bachelor of Computer Science - Joint Honours)
topics: Linear Algebra 1 (Advanced Level)
Email: karigiannis@uwaterloo.ca
This course is a rigorous treatment of the theory of finite dimensional vector spaces over an arbitrary field.
We also cover the theory of determinants over an arbitrary commutative ring with identity, and some aspects of the theory of polynomials in one variable over a field.

The ultimate goal is the Primary Decomposition Theorem, which characterizes a linear operator on a finite dimensional vector space in terms of invariant subspaces annihilated by the primary factors of its minimal polynomial.
We will cover a large amount of difficult material at a fast pace.
Understand and apply the concepts of the theory of abstract vector spaces and linear operators on finite-dimensional vector spaces.
fields; systems of linear equations; matrices; row-reduced echelon form; matrix algebra; invertible matrices
vector spaces; subspaces; bases and dimension; coordinates; row equivalence
algebra of linear maps; isomorphism; representations by matrices; dual space; transpose of a linear map
commutative rings; existence and uniqueness of determinants; multilinear maps; the exterior algebra
eigenvalues; annihilating polynomials; invariant subspaces; simultaneous triangulation and diagonalization
Much (but not all) of my lectures will closely follow the first six chapters of this book:
“Linear Algebra: Second Edition” by Kenneth Hoffman and Ray Kunze; Prentice Hall, 1971.
“Linear Algebra: Fourth Edition” by Friedberg, Insel, and Spence; Prentice-Hall, 2003.
The assignments are an integral part of your evaluation in this course and I encourage everyone to take them very seriously.
There will be no opportunity for a make-up midterm test.

major_name: Computer Science (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Introduction to Computational Mathematics Winter 2025
A rigorous introduction to the field of computational mathematics.
The focus is on the interplay between continuous models and their solution via discrete processes.
Topics include pitfalls in computation, solution of linear systems, interpolation, discrete Fourier transforms, and numerical integration.
Explain the shortcomings of finite precision arithmetic
Analyze problems in terms of conditioning, and algorithms in terms of stability
Know some common and basic algorithms in computational mathematics, e.g. Numerical solution of linear systems, Numerical Integration, etc.
Apply these algorithms to solve problems from various domains

Basics of digital logic design.
Data representation and manipulation.
Basics of processor design.

This course enables students to develop an accurate mental model of the architecture and organization of physical computers and it introduces them to theoretical and practical concepts relevant to the structure and design of modern digital computers.

Design simple combinational and sequential hardware at the logic gate level in order to implement simple algorithms and computations, such as addition, multiplication, and data-path control for processors.
Describe number systems used by computer hardware, including IEEE floating point and two's complement.
Analyze how machine language is executed by hardware, and describe a simple pipelined processor architecture for executing a RISC machine language.
Explain basic cache and virtual-memory architectures, and how they can impact performance.
Introduction and ARM (~3 hours)
Combinational logic and basic components.
Basic Processor Design (~9 hours)
Processor design using single-cycle control.
Multi-cycle control.
Virtual memory.
Multi-processor systems and core processors.
Patterson and Hennessy: "Computer Organization and Design".

major_name: Human-Computer Interaction Specialization
topics: Human-Computer Interaction Fall 2024
LEC - Monday 10-11:30am DC 1350
An introduction to the fundamental theories, methods, and research in the design and evaluation of novel computational artifacts designed to meet real-world human needs.
Through lectures and design activities, students work in teams of 5 to design a solution for a real-world problem.
The end result of the team project is a high-fidelity interactive prototype of a mobile application, targeted at solving a particular real-world problem.
Identify the primary luminaries in Interactive Design and HCI
Identify your target users
Design studies to understand your users and their needs within a sociocultural context
Create user data-driven designs and prototypes of different levels of fidelity
Design studies to evaluate designs during different stages of the project
Properly gather and analyze qualitative and quantitative data from semi-structured interviews, paper prototype evaluation, heuristic evaluations and cognitive walkthrough
Discover a variety of HCI research methodologies
Add a high-quality design of an interesting product to your design portfolio
The success of a team project depends critically on each student being a responsible member of the team, i.e., showing up and participating.
Special consideration can be made for a few exceptions (e.g., academic travel, illnesses and family emergencies).

topics: Engineering and Peace Fall 2024

This course is built on the conviction that the kinds of problems engineers seek to address, and the ways they seek to address them, should matter for anyone interested in advancing peace in the world.
Topics include historical connections between the discipline of engineering and warfare, understanding the engineering method and mindset, and technological frontiers for peacebuilding.
Augment their approach to analyzing and solving problems with insights from both engineering and peacebuilding theory and practice; and
Identify opportunities to apply their expertise and passions to make a meaningful social impact

topics: Human-Computer Interaction Fall 2024

An introduction to the fundamental theories, methods, and research in the design and evaluation of novel computational artifacts designed to meet real-world human needs.
Through lectures and design activities, students work in teams of 5 to design a solution for a real-world problem.
The end result of the team project is a high-fidelity interactive prototype of a mobile application, targeted at solving a particular real-world problem.
Identify the primary luminaries in Interactive Design and HCI
Identify your target users
Design studies to understand your users and their needs within a sociocultural context
Create user data-driven designs and prototypes of different levels of fidelity
Design studies to evaluate designs during different stages of the project
Properly gather and analyze qualitative and quantitative data from semi-structured interviews, paper prototype evaluation, heuristic evaluations and cognitive walkthrough
Discover a variety of HCI research methodologies
Add a high-quality design of an interesting product to your design portfolio
The success of a team project depends critically on each student being a responsible member of the team, i.e., showing up and participating.

major_name: Data Science (Bachelor of Computer Science - Honours)
topics: Linear Algebra 1 (Advanced Level)
Email: karigiannis@uwaterloo.ca
This course is a rigorous treatment of the theory of finite dimensional vector spaces over an arbitrary field.
We also cover the theory of determinants over an arbitrary commutative ring with identity, and some aspects of the theory of polynomials in one variable over a field.

The ultimate goal is the Primary Decomposition Theorem, which characterizes a linear operator on a finite dimensional vector space in terms of invariant subspaces annihilated by the primary factors of its minimal polynomial.
We will cover a large amount of difficult material at a fast pace.
Understand and apply the concepts of the theory of abstract vector spaces and linear operators on finite-dimensional vector spaces.
fields; systems of linear equations; matrices; row-reduced echelon form; matrix algebra; invertible matrices
vector spaces; subspaces; bases and dimension; coordinates; row equivalence
algebra of linear maps; isomorphism; representations by matrices; dual space; transpose of a linear map
commutative rings; existence and uniqueness of determinants; multilinear maps; the exterior algebra
eigenvalues; annihilating polynomials; invariant subspaces; simultaneous triangulation and diagonalization
Much (but not all) of my lectures will closely follow the first six chapters of this book:
“Linear Algebra: Second Edition” by Kenneth Hoffman and Ray Kunze; Prentice Hall, 1971.
“Linear Algebra: Fourth Edition” by Friedberg, Insel, and Spence; Prentice-Hall, 2003.
The assignments are an integral part of your evaluation in this course and I encourage everyone to take them very seriously.
There will be no opportunity for a make-up midterm test.

This course enables students to develop an accurate mental model of the architecture and organization of physical computers and it introduces them to theoretical and practical concepts relevant to the structure and design of modern digital computers.

Design simple combinational and sequential hardware at the logic gate level in order to implement simple algorithms and computations, such as addition, multiplication, and data-path control for processors.
Describe number systems used by computer hardware, including IEEE floating point and two's complement.

Explain basic cache and virtual-memory architectures, and how they can impact performance.

topics: Notice of Recording
Engineering Biomedical Economics Fall 2024
This course examines key economic issues in health care and biomedical industries.
Topics include the market for medical care, health insurance, various models of healthcare delivery and competition and the role of government in policy, financing and delivery of health care.
This course will train students to use economic analysis to model and understand the complex interactions between health care delivery, insurance markets, health innovators, governments, and firms.
Articulate differences between healthcare systems and how incentives affect the system economics.
Articulate differences between healthcare systems and how incentives affect the system economics.
Investigate a research topic in the area of health economics.
Apply cost-benefit analysis to aid in healthcare decision making.

A knowledge base for engineering:   Demonstrated competence in university level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the biomedical engineering program.
2. Problem analysis:  An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

Investigation:  An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.

4. Design:  An ability to design solutions for complex, open-ended engineering problems and to design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate attention to health and safety risks, applicable standards, and economic, environmental, cultural and societal considerations.
7. Communication skills:  An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.

Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking and listening, and the ability to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.
Professionalism:   An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.

Such ability includes an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society, the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.

Life-long learning:  An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world in ways sufficient to maintain their competence and to allow them to contribute to the advancement of knowledge.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Biomedical Engineering Ethics Winter 2025
I can also be reached by Teams for all virtual meetings.

This course explores ethical issues in biomedical engineering practice, including professional ethics, medical ethics, the ethics of human and animal subject use in biomedical research, and the impact of biomedical engineering solutions on society and the environment.

This course aims to guide students in understanding the complex relationships between design, biomedical technologies and society and to appreciate how such an understanding can improve design outcomes from the user, community, national, and global perspectives.

Identify and evaluate considerations that influence ethical decisions regarding design, modification, and use of biomedical technologies, and the ethical concepts and arguments relevant to these practices (6 a, b, c; 7 a, b; 10 a, b, c);
Create rational solutions to ethical situations of concern related to biomedical engineering (6, 7);
Demonstrate an understanding of the social responsibilities of biomedical engineers (8 a, b);
Describe the importance of social factors affecting development, uptake, and impact of biomedical technologies on society in both developed and developing countries (7, 8).
This course will focus on and primarily measure your aptitude in the following graduate attributes:
Demonstrate knowledge of effective team attributes and processes
Communication skills  An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.

Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking and listening, and the ability to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.
Can present information, arguments and analyses accurately and reliably within the profession and to society at large using appropriate documentation and vocabulary
Professionalism  An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.
Articulate the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society with reference to the protection of the public and its interest.
Describe the importance of codes, standards, best practices, laws, and biomedical regulations within engineering.
Identify ethical and unethical behaviour in professional situations (including the use of biomedical technologies).
in engineering projects.

In this course students in Architectural, Civil, Environmental, and Geological Engineering will enhance oral and written communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession.
In this course, you will work to enhance your written and oral technical communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession as well as to your future career.

More generally, in this course, you should anticipate learning what professional norms of technical communication and dominant forms of sharing knowledge prevail within and across the fields of engineering.
Yet this course also attempts to impart awareness and appreciation for how these communicative forms are matters of social context and sites of negotiation and contestation.

By extension, this progression also encourages you to find a place and voice in the conversations within your fields of study and to reflect upon the meaning and shape of available forums for technical communication.
I perceive our classroom as a co-constructed space, in which readings and discussions may frequently challenge your attitudes, your unconsciously held beliefs, or your positions on current issues.
To ensure a safe and open space in which all can converse and learn productively, it is vital that we conduct our relationships with respect and an ethic of care.
Describe and apply conventions, genres, norms, and values of communication in an engineering discipline;
Compose persuasive, audience-specific technical arguments;
Analyze and summarice technical content in clear and concise ways;
Deliver effective oral presentations; and
Appraise and reflect on their own compositions, and those of their peers, to strategically revise and edit documents and presentations
Objectives for Students of Communication Studies
You (students) will understand the complexity of communication as a human process of shared meaning-making in the context of power, history, and culture.

You will increase your capacity to recognize and enhance yours and others’ agency – the ability to make a difference in the world for yourself and others – and understand the implications of your communication behaviors for yourself and others.
Recognize diverse linguistic practices and modes of communication as resources for writers and speakers.

You will understand communication as a practice, and improve your critical and creative communication competencies by developing your ability to use writing, speaking, and other media of communication to create effective and engaging artifacts.

Your will reflect on your role in fostering the public good (the multifaceted well-being of individuals and groups), begin to imagine a better future, and make decisions in your communication that can transform the communities to which you belong.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: D. Shakespeare
In this course students in Computer, Electrical, and Management Engineering will enhance oral and written communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession.

By participating in classes and completing course assignments, you will practice genres of communication crafted for audiences that might include employers, clients, peer groups, technical staff, public audiences, and regulatory and policy-focused stakeholders.
By focusing on genre, design, and audience, you will come to better understand concepts including meaning-making, perception, and responsibility.
More generally, in this course, students can and should learn professional norms of technical communication and dominant forms of sharing knowledge within the fields of engineering.
Yet this course also attempts to teach students how these communicative forms are matters of social context and sites of negotiation and contestation.
We also hope students will find their place and voice in the conversations in their fields of study and reflect on the meaning and shape of available forums for technical communication.

compose persuasive, audience-specific technical arguments
analyze and summarize technical content in a clear and concise way

major_name: Bachelor of Mathematics Degree Requirements
topics: Applied Linear Algebra 1 Winter 2025
Systems of linear equations.
Introduction to vector spaces.
We will see how to solve systems of linear equations using matrix methods before studying matrices as algebraic objects in their own right.
Next, we will learn about the fundamental concepts of span, linear independence, and basis and learn how to determine whether a set is a subspace of Rn.
After studying subspaces, we will study linear mappings, which map subspaces to subspaces.
We will discuss the geometric interpretation of these mappings and study their fundamental subspaces.
Finally, we will learn how to calculate the determinant of a matrix and use this knowledge to diagonalize square matrices.
Provide a graphical and algebraic description of vectors, lines, and planes in R^n
Model and solve mathematical and discipline-specific problems using systems of linear equations
Perform basic algebraic operations on matrices
Given a set of vectors in R^n, determine whether it is linearly independent, a spanning set of R^n, or a basis of R^n
Given a basis and a vector in standard coordinates, use matrix methods to calculate its coordinate vectors
Given a set in R^n, determine whether it is a subspace of R^n
Given a mapping L: R^n --> R^m, determine whether it is linear
Given a linear mapping, choose the appropriate algorithm find a basis for each of its fundamental subspaces
Given a square matrix, calculate its determinant and provide a geometric interpretation of this value
Communicate ideas and concepts relating to linear algebra using accurate mathematical language and notation

major_name: Bachelor of Mathematics Degree Requirements
topics: Linear Algebra 1 (Advanced Level)
Email: karigiannis@uwaterloo.ca
This course is a rigorous treatment of the theory of finite dimensional vector spaces over an arbitrary field.
We also cover the theory of determinants over an arbitrary commutative ring with identity, and some aspects of the theory of polynomials in one variable over a field.

The ultimate goal is the Primary Decomposition Theorem, which characterizes a linear operator on a finite dimensional vector space in terms of invariant subspaces annihilated by the primary factors of its minimal polynomial.
We will cover a large amount of difficult material at a fast pace.
Understand and apply the concepts of the theory of abstract vector spaces and linear operators on finite-dimensional vector spaces.

This course teaches the forms of science fiction present in modern science fiction and science fiction throughout history, in literature and other media forms.
What purpose does science fiction serve in our lives?

In particular, we will center on three subgenres of science fiction, aliens, robots, and time travel, to examine how and why science fiction creators and science fiction fans keep returning to these ideas.

course_name: MATH228 - Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry (0.50)
major_name: Earth Sciences - Geophysics Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry Winter 2025
First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients, series solutions and special functions, the Laplace transform method.
Applications in physics and chemistry are emphasized.
Differential equations capture how some variable of interest, such as the position of a planet, changes as a function of some independent variable, such as time.
Differential equations are very widely used in the sciences because of the broad range of real-world phenomena they can describe in a mathematical framework.

In this course, students will be introduced to the universe of differential equations, including first-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, the Laplace transform method, and both exact and numerical methods for solving differential equations.
Applications in physics and chemistry will be emphasized.
understand how differential equations can be used to model physical systems,

major_name: Earth Sciences - Geophysics Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Applied Linear Algebra 1 Winter 2025
Systems of linear equations.
Introduction to vector spaces.
We will see how to solve systems of linear equations using matrix methods before studying matrices as algebraic objects in their own right.
Next, we will learn about the fundamental concepts of span, linear independence, and basis and learn how to determine whether a set is a subspace of Rn.
After studying subspaces, we will study linear mappings, which map subspaces to subspaces.
We will discuss the geometric interpretation of these mappings and study their fundamental subspaces.
Finally, we will learn how to calculate the determinant of a matrix and use this knowledge to diagonalize square matrices.

topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.

course_name: MATH103 - Introductory Algebra for Arts and Social Science (0.50)
major_name: Earth Sciences - Geophysics Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Introductory Algebra for Arts and Social Science Winter 2025
Email: jen.nelson@uwaterloo.ca
Topics will be chosen from linear equations, systems of linear equations, linear inequalities, functions, set theory, permutations and combinations, binomial theorem, probability theory.
The course begins with a review of operations with real numbers and fundamental algebra skills.
The solutions of polynomial equations, both linear and quadratic, in one and two variables and their graphical representation are studied.
An extension is made to linear systems with their solutions being expressed both algebraically and graphically.
To solve linear systems, matrices and the associated row reduction strategies are used.
The relationship between exponential functions and logarithmic functions is examined.
The basic properties of logarithms are introduced and used to solve logarithmic and exponential equations.
Various applications involving exponential growth and decay and logarithmic scales are presented.
Concepts in set theory and counting theory support the study of probability theory.
Perform operations with real numbers and algebraic expressions.
Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including those involving absolute value, and represent the solutions algebraically and graphically.
Solve a system of linear equations using matrix operations, introducing a free variable, or parameter as appropriate.
Solve quadratic equations in one variable.
Recognize that the solutions to a quadratic equation in two variables lie on a curve known as a parabola and analyze the properties of a parabola.
Describe the relationship between an exponential function and a logarithmic function.
Use the properties of logarithms to solve logarithmic and exponential equations, and to solve problems involving exponential growth and decay, and logarithmic scales.
Use the appropriate symbols and language in set theory to perform set operations, represent sets and subsets using Venn diagrams, and apply the counting principles for sets in real-life situations.

course_name: MATH104 - Introductory Calculus for Arts and Social Science (0.50)
major_name: Earth Sciences - Geophysics Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Introductory Calculus for Arts and Social Science Winter 2025
The major concepts introduced to solve problems are rate of change, optimization, growth and decay, and integration.
This course provides an introduction to the applications of differential and integral calculus in business, the behavioural sciences, and the social sciences.
A special type of limit will give rise to the derivative, the central idea in differential calculus.

The interpretation of the derivative in applications such as rates of change and optimization, where the situations can be modelled by algebraic, exponential, or logarithmic functions, will be examined.
The concepts of the antiderivative and the indefinite integral will be studied.
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus will relate the integral to the derivative.
The problem of calculating the area under a curve will lead to the definite integral, a basic concept of integral calculus.
The interpretation of the integral in various applications will be studied.
be able to interpret a limit, given the graph of a function;
evaluate the limit of a function using appropriate techniques;
determine the derivative of polynomial functions using the definition of a derivative;
determine the derivative of algebraic, exponential, and logarithmic functions using the techniques of differentiation;
apply the derivative to determining equations of tangents, graphing functions, solving rate problems, and solving optimization problems;
determine general and unique antiderivatives;
determine the indefinite integral of a function using the techniques of integration;
determine definite integrals; and

course_name: MATH228 - Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry (0.50)
major_name: Earth Sciences - Hydrogeology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry Winter 2025
First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients, series solutions and special functions, the Laplace transform method.
Applications in physics and chemistry are emphasized.
Differential equations capture how some variable of interest, such as the position of a planet, changes as a function of some independent variable, such as time.
Differential equations are very widely used in the sciences because of the broad range of real-world phenomena they can describe in a mathematical framework.

In this course, students will be introduced to the universe of differential equations, including first-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, the Laplace transform method, and both exact and numerical methods for solving differential equations.
Applications in physics and chemistry will be emphasized.

major_name: Earth Sciences - Hydrogeology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Applied Linear Algebra 1 Winter 2025
Systems of linear equations.
Introduction to vector spaces.
We will see how to solve systems of linear equations using matrix methods before studying matrices as algebraic objects in their own right.
Next, we will learn about the fundamental concepts of span, linear independence, and basis and learn how to determine whether a set is a subspace of Rn.
After studying subspaces, we will study linear mappings, which map subspaces to subspaces.
We will discuss the geometric interpretation of these mappings and study their fundamental subspaces.
Finally, we will learn how to calculate the determinant of a matrix and use this knowledge to diagonalize square matrices.
Provide a graphical and algebraic description of vectors, lines, and planes in R^n

Given a mapping L: R^n --> R^m, determine whether it is linear
Given a linear mapping, choose the appropriate algorithm find a basis for each of its fundamental subspaces
Given a square matrix, calculate its determinant and provide a geometric interpretation of this value

topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.

course_name: COMMST192 - Communication in the Engineering Profession (COMPE, ELE, MGTE) (0.50)
major_name: Electrical Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: D. Shakespeare
In this course students in Computer, Electrical, and Management Engineering will enhance oral and written communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession.

By participating in classes and completing course assignments, you will practice genres of communication crafted for audiences that might include employers, clients, peer groups, technical staff, public audiences, and regulatory and policy-focused stakeholders.
By focusing on genre, design, and audience, you will come to better understand concepts including meaning-making, perception, and responsibility.
More generally, in this course, students can and should learn professional norms of technical communication and dominant forms of sharing knowledge within the fields of engineering.
Yet this course also attempts to teach students how these communicative forms are matters of social context and sites of negotiation and contestation.
We also hope students will find their place and voice in the conversations in their fields of study and reflect on the meaning and shape of available forums for technical communication.
describe and apply conventions, genres, and norms, and values of communication in an engineering discipline
compose persuasive, audience-specific technical arguments
analyze and summarize technical content in a clear and concise way
You (students) will understand the complexity of communication as a human process of shared meaning-making in the context of power, history, and culture.

You will increase your capacity to recognize and enhance yours and others’ agency – the ability to make a difference in the world for yourself and others – and understand the implications of your communication behaviours for yourself and others.
You will recognize diverse linguistic practices and modes of communication as resources for writers and speakers.

You will understand communication as a practice, and improve your critical and creative communication competencies by developing your ability to use writing, speaking, and other media of communication to create effective and engaging artifacts.

You will reflect on your role in fostering the public good (the multifaceted well-being of individuals and groups), begin to imagine a better future, and make decisions in your communication that can transform the communities to which you belong.
4 September Introduction to the Course "The Art of Communicating Science" (TED) acquire course text
9 September Introduction to Rhetoric; Facts, Evidence, and Opinions Crowley & Hawhee; McBrayer read assigned texts
18 November Ethics for Engineers in-class texts
27 November Discourse and Power

kerstin.dautenhahn@uwaterloo.ca
ECE 750:
View requirements for ECE 750
View requirements for ECE 493
The course will provide an introduction to the research field of social robotics, with a particular human-centered perspective.

Robots that can interact socially in an effective and acceptable manner with people have become increasingly important for applications ranging from robot-assisted therapy for people with special needs, robotic assistants for older people and care home residents, robots as tools in education or robotic co-workers for a new generation of  industrial robot that emphasize human-machine collaboration and communication.

Students will gain an understanding of the concepts and theories underlying social robotics, as well as research methodologies and techniques to realize socially intelligent robots and design, plan and evaluate human-robot interaction experiments.
Understand concepts and theories underlying social robotics
Apply research methodologies and techniques to realize socially intelligent robots
Design, plan, and evaluate human-robot interaction experiments
Demonstrate scientific writing and presentation skills
Explain how psychology and social sciences can inform the engineering of social robots
Understand basic principles of sensors, actuators and multi-model interaction and communication for social robots
Explain examples of robot computational architectures used in human-robot interaction
Definitions of social robots and requirements of robots’ social skill and their relevance to robotics and Artificial Intelligence in real-world applications
The role of affective expressions of social robots and modelling emotions to facilitate human-robot engagement
Evaluating usability, user experience and acceptance of social robots
Guidelines of how to write up social robotics research for a scientific publication
Overview of cognitive architectures for socially intelligent robots
Featuring interdisciplinary research in social robotics based on research from other fields, e.g. from (developmental) psychology, ethology or primatology
Roles of social robots in human society and their potential impact on society and wellbeing
Selected examples of applications of social robots e.g. in care, therapy, education, rehabilitation and co-worker scenarios will be discussed throughout the course
Ethical, safety and privacy issues as relevant to social robotics will be discussed throughout the course
Course Grading for Graduate Students:

20% Individual discussion paper: Students will reflect on work in Science Fiction involving the concepts of social and intelligent robots, and reflect on the relevance to today’s robotics technology in robotics and Artificial Intelligence.
Students can choose the work and discuss the selection with the instructor.

Students are required to write a report that motivates, describes and discusses those behaviours in light of the state of the art literature, and describe an experimental design for a human-robot interaction experiment where those behaviours could be tested and analyzed.

Specifically, students’ reports will be evaluated based on a) the literature review demonstrating the level of knowledge in this domain, b) the relevance of the identified research questions and hypotheses, c) the depth of the proposed research program, d) the range, complexity and quality of the implemented and documented robot behaviours, e) the detailed description of the methodology used to carry out and analyze this program of work, f) the user study conducted and how results are presented and analysed, and finally, g) a critical evaluation of possible limitations of the expected outcomes and backup plans in order to address  possible delays and technical difficulties encountered during the implementation of the work.
Note, those skills can also be applied to related fields of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI), Human Factors etc.

20% Individual discussion paper: Students will reflect on work in Science Fiction involving the concepts of social and intelligent robots, and reflect on the relevance to today’s robotics technology in robotics and Artificial Intelligence.
Students can choose the work and discuss the selection with the instructor.

Students are required to write a report that motivates, describes and discusses those behaviours in light of the state of the art literature, and describe a possible experimental design for a human-robot interaction experiment where those implemented behaviours could be tested and analyzed.

Specifically, students’ reports will be evaluated based on a) the literature review demonstrating the level of knowledge in this domain, b) the relevance of the identified research questions and hypotheses, c) the depth of the proposed research program, d) the range, complexity and quality of the implemented and documented robot behaviours, e) the detailed description of the methodology used to carry out and analyze this program of work, f) a critical evaluation of possible limitations of the expected outcomes and backup plans in order to address  possible delays and technical difficulties encountered during the implementation of the work.
Note, those skills can also be applied to related fields of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI), Human Factors etc.

I am teaching multiple communication courses, and especially early in the sememster, I cannot always quickly know whch course you are referring to just from your email.
In this course students in Architectural, Civil, Environmental, and Geological Engineering will enhance oral and written communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession.
In this course, you will work to enhance your written and oral technical communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession as well as to your future career.

More generally, in this course, you should anticipate learning what professional norms of technical communication and dominant forms of sharing knowledge prevail within and across the fields of engineering.
Yet this course also attempts to impart awareness and appreciation for how these communicative forms are matters of social context and sites of negotiation and contestation.

By extension, this progression also encourages you to find a place and voice in the conversations within your fields of study and to reflect upon the meaning and shape of available forums for technical communication.
I perceive our classroom as a co-constructed space, in which readings and discussions may frequently challenge your attitudes, your unconsciously held beliefs, or your positions on current issues.
To ensure a safe and open space in which all can converse and learn productively, it is vital that we conduct our relationships with respect and an ethic of care.
Describe and apply conventions, genres, norms, and values of communication in an engineering discipline;
Compose persuasive, audience-specific technical arguments;
Analyze and summarice technical content in clear and concise ways;
Deliver effective oral presentations; and
Appraise and reflect on their own compositions, and those of their peers, to strategically revise and edit documents and presentations
Objectives for Students of Communication Studies
You (students) will understand the complexity of communication as a human process of shared meaning-making in the context of power, history, and culture.

You will increase your capacity to recognize and enhance yours and others’ agency – the ability to make a difference in the world for yourself and others – and understand the implications of your communication behaviors for yourself and others.
Recognize diverse linguistic practices and modes of communication as resources for writers and speakers.

You will understand communication as a practice, and improve your critical and creative communication competencies by developing your ability to use writing, speaking, and other media of communication to create effective and engaging artifacts.

Your will reflect on your role in fostering the public good (the multifaceted well-being of individuals and groups), begin to imagine a better future, and make decisions in your communication that can transform the communities to which you belong.

The main assignments in the course function as parts of a whole: the pitch, progress report, proposal, and reflection form a course-long project whose theme and structure you should consider from the start of the term.

The proposal, in addition to being a well-conceived, clearly structured, and persuasive document, is intended to communicate an engineering idea you wish to pursue, an idea you will first present through the pitch email.
We will discuss how to do this in our first weeks together.

The student has only one self-declared short-term absence per term and this absence can only be used during the formal lecture period.

The course develops a geological knowledge for applications to any physical environment and provides an appreciation of the impact of engineering work on the environment.
Topics include mineral and rock identification, the rock cycle, structural geology and tectonics, geology of Canada, effects of water, ice and wind.
Students are also introduced to the concept of geologic time, topographic and geologic maps, and the basic principles and tools used to determine geologic history.
Gain insight into why engineers are continually challenged by the science behind a complex and changing earth.
Understand and apply engineering design principles in the context of a changing earth.
Gain basic experience in identifying earth materials and in earth material testing.
Establish the academic background required to take advanced earth sciences and geotechnical engineering courses.
Geology and Soils Labs: This course includes seven laboratory sessions that will be held during the term.
Students need to self-organize into case study groups, with the same number of students in each group.

course_name: ENVE335 - Decision Making for Environmental Engineers (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Decision Making for Environmental Engineers Winter 2025
DWE 3518
Decision-making, optimization, and assessment of environmental and water resource systems, and the design process in environmental engineering.
Multi-criteria decision-making methods for concept and embodiment engineering design phases.
Risk-based system performance metrics and trend tests.
Uncertainty estimation via First-Order Uncertainty Analysis and Monte Carlo Simulation.
Formulation and solution of linear, integer, and nonlinear optimization models.
Sensitivity analysis for decision-making and descriptive (numerical) models.
Each discipline contributes distinct standards and focuses that enhance both the foundational and practical aspects of decision science.
This course is specifically tailored to introduce environmental engineers to decision-making theories and methodologies pertinent to addressing environmental sustainability issues.
Instead, we aim to equip students with critical knowledge and practical skills essential for making informed decisions that address sustainability challenges.
Demonstrate an understanding of the complexities involved in decision-making processes for addressing environmental sustainability issues.
Develop and apply a mathematical framework using systems thinking to articulate and analyze decision-making problems in environmental engineering.
Acquire skills to solve decision-making problems using various methods, including decision trees, multi-criteria decision making, and both single and multi-objective optimization.
Gain insights into recognizing and evaluating the uncertainties inherent in decision-making and will learn to apply stochastic optimization techniques in uncertain scenarios.
Broaden their knowledge and interest in advanced decision science methodologies to tackle complex issues in environmental sustainability.
Theory and Framework

Engineering Design and decision trees

Introduction
Design Process

Sustainability considerations must be central to the proposed project.
While research (i.e., discovery of new knowledge) may be an important component of engineering design, research-only projects are not appropriate for Engineering Capstone Design Projects.
A five-person team will require a special plan to do more work than the normal four person teams.
Each design team will choose an appropriate Environmental/Geological engineering problem that reflects the interests of the team members.
Teams must select a challenging design problem.
A challenging problem is one where you have few, if any, alternative designs in mind to start the project.
Outstanding grades are possible even if you can’t demonstrate clear innovation in the projects.
Teams must demonstrate that a range of design alternatives were considered.
Teams must quantitatively evaluate multiple alternatives and multiple design objectives/constraints (e.g., engineering analysis and engineering decision-making).

The standard project will demonstrate this alternative generation and decision-making in this 400 course, however, in some projects, it could be more natural to save the alternative generation and decision-making application to the next term (in 401).
Such an arrangement must be approved on a case-by-case basis by Professor Tolson who may choose to consult with your technical advisor.

major_name: Environmental Sciences - Ecology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.
More detailed information about the course elements which contribute to the final grade will be given in the learn sight and in future outline updates

course_name: MATH103 - Introductory Algebra for Arts and Social Science (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Sciences - Geoscience Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Introductory Algebra for Arts and Social Science Winter 2025
Email: jen.nelson@uwaterloo.ca
Topics will be chosen from linear equations, systems of linear equations, linear inequalities, functions, set theory, permutations and combinations, binomial theorem, probability theory.
The course begins with a review of operations with real numbers and fundamental algebra skills.
The solutions of polynomial equations, both linear and quadratic, in one and two variables and their graphical representation are studied.
An extension is made to linear systems with their solutions being expressed both algebraically and graphically.
To solve linear systems, matrices and the associated row reduction strategies are used.
The relationship between exponential functions and logarithmic functions is examined.
The basic properties of logarithms are introduced and used to solve logarithmic and exponential equations.
Various applications involving exponential growth and decay and logarithmic scales are presented.
Concepts in set theory and counting theory support the study of probability theory.
Perform operations with real numbers and algebraic expressions.
Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including those involving absolute value, and represent the solutions algebraically and graphically.
Solve a system of linear equations using matrix operations, introducing a free variable, or parameter as appropriate.
Solve quadratic equations in one variable.
Recognize that the solutions to a quadratic equation in two variables lie on a curve known as a parabola and analyze the properties of a parabola.
Describe the relationship between an exponential function and a logarithmic function.
Use the properties of logarithms to solve logarithmic and exponential equations, and to solve problems involving exponential growth and decay, and logarithmic scales.
Use the appropriate symbols and language in set theory to perform set operations, represent sets and subsets using Venn diagrams, and apply the counting principles for sets in real-life situations.
1.1 Real Numbers
1.2 Order of Operations
1.3 Fundamental Algebraic Skills
Unit 2: Equations and Inequalities
2.1 Equations in One Variable
Unit 2: Equations and Inequalities Continued
2.3 Multivariate Equations
Unit 3: Systems of Linear Equations and Matrices
3.1 Systems of Linear Equations
3.2 Introduction to Matrices and Elementary Row Operations
Unit 3: Systems of Linear Equations and Matrices Continued
3.3 Applications
3.4 Systems With No Solutions and Systems With an Infinite Number of Solutions
Unit 4: Quadratic Equations and Functions
4.1 Quadratic Equations in One Variable
4.2 Quadratic Equations in Two Variables and the Parabola
4.3 Quadratic Functions
4.4 Applications
Unit 5: Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
5.1 Exponential Functions and Equations
5.2 Exponential Functions and Logarithmic Functions
Unit 5: Exponential and Logarithmic Functions Continued
5.4 Solving Logarithmic and Exponential Equations
5.5 Applications
6.1 Introduction to Sets
6.2 Set Operations
6.3 Counting Principles for Sets
7.2 Combinations of Simple Events — Compound Events
7.4 An Introduction to Random Variables and Probability Functions
8.1 Counting Principles and Probability
8.3 Combinations — Unordered Selections
8.4 Binomial Models

course_name: MATH104 - Introductory Calculus for Arts and Social Science (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Sciences - Geoscience Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Introductory Calculus for Arts and Social Science Winter 2025
The major concepts introduced to solve problems are rate of change, optimization, growth and decay, and integration.
This course provides an introduction to the applications of differential and integral calculus in business, the behavioural sciences, and the social sciences.
A special type of limit will give rise to the derivative, the central idea in differential calculus.

The interpretation of the derivative in applications such as rates of change and optimization, where the situations can be modelled by algebraic, exponential, or logarithmic functions, will be examined.
The concepts of the antiderivative and the indefinite integral will be studied.
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus will relate the integral to the derivative.
The problem of calculating the area under a curve will lead to the definite integral, a basic concept of integral calculus.
The interpretation of the integral in various applications will be studied.
be able to interpret a limit, given the graph of a function;
evaluate the limit of a function using appropriate techniques;
determine the derivative of polynomial functions using the definition of a derivative;
determine the derivative of algebraic, exponential, and logarithmic functions using the techniques of differentiation;
apply the derivative to determining equations of tangents, graphing functions, solving rate problems, and solving optimization problems;

topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;

interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.
