course_name: COMMST191 - Communication in the Engineering Profession (AE, CIVE, ENVE, GEOE) (0.50)
major_name: Geological Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: jclausen@uwaterloo.ca (please do not use the D2L email system)
I monitor my email M-F, 9:00 am - 5:00 pm.
I am teaching multiple communication courses, and especially early in the sememster, I cannot always quickly know whch course you are referring to just from your email.
In this course students in Architectural, Civil, Environmental, and Geological Engineering will enhance oral and written communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession.
In this course, you will work to enhance your written and oral technical communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession as well as to your future career.

More generally, in this course, you should anticipate learning what professional norms of technical communication and dominant forms of sharing knowledge prevail within and across the fields of engineering.
Yet this course also attempts to impart awareness and appreciation for how these communicative forms are matters of social context and sites of negotiation and contestation.

By extension, this progression also encourages you to find a place and voice in the conversations within your fields of study and to reflect upon the meaning and shape of available forums for technical communication.
I perceive our classroom as a co-constructed space, in which readings and discussions may frequently challenge your attitudes, your unconsciously held beliefs, or your positions on current issues.
To ensure a safe and open space in which all can converse and learn productively, it is vital that we conduct our relationships with respect and an ethic of care.
Describe and apply conventions, genres, norms, and values of communication in an engineering discipline;
Compose persuasive, audience-specific technical arguments;
Analyze and summarice technical content in clear and concise ways;
Deliver effective oral presentations; and
Appraise and reflect on their own compositions, and those of their peers, to strategically revise and edit documents and presentations
Objectives for Students of Communication Studies
You (students) will understand the complexity of communication as a human process of shared meaning-making in the context of power, history, and culture.

You will increase your capacity to recognize and enhance yours and others’ agency – the ability to make a difference in the world for yourself and others – and understand the implications of your communication behaviors for yourself and others.
Recognize diverse linguistic practices and modes of communication as resources for writers and speakers.

You will understand communication as a practice, and improve your critical and creative communication competencies by developing your ability to use writing, speaking, and other media of communication to create effective and engaging artifacts.

Your will reflect on your role in fostering the public good (the multifaceted well-being of individuals and groups), begin to imagine a better future, and make decisions in your communication that can transform the communities to which you belong.

A formal policy brief includes the following sections:
Executive summary
Explanation of results
identify and address a specific policy-making audience
explain the current research on this topic in clear, non-technical language
highlight the features of the research most relevant for policy makers and stakeholders
make one or two recommendations based on your synthesis of the research

The course develops a geological knowledge for applications to any physical environment and provides an appreciation of the impact of engineering work on the environment.
Topics include mineral and rock identification, the rock cycle, structural geology and tectonics, geology of Canada, effects of water, ice and wind.
Students are also introduced to the concept of geologic time, topographic and geologic maps, and the basic principles and tools used to determine geologic history.
Gain insight into why engineers are continually challenged by the science behind a complex and changing earth.
Understand and apply engineering design principles in the context of a changing earth.
Gain basic experience in identifying earth materials and in earth material testing.
Establish the academic background required to take advanced earth sciences and geotechnical engineering courses.
Geology and Soils Labs: This course includes seven laboratory sessions that will be held during the term.
Students need to self-organize into case study groups, with the same number of students in each group.

Describe the relationship between geology and the design and performance of engineered structures (buildings, dams, slopes, tunnels, excavations, and infrastructure) as well as the implications of damaging geological processes for the siting and security of engineering facilities.

Understand basic concepts in engineering geology as applied to rock and soil such as material properties, variability in properties, the role of external factors such as stress history, evaluation of design quality in the context of geology and geological processes, site investigation and field techniques used to characterize the mass properties of geological materials, and their use in engineering geology inputs into the design and construction process

Wednesdays, 11:30am - 2:20pm - DWE 1502

The objectives are to summarize geological conditions and structural setting of the mine, to outline geohazard exposure for slope design (e.g., seismicity), identify key engineering geological problems in pit slope stability (including failure types, failure mechanisms, and failure mitigation), and to discuss issues related to the stability and characteristics of associated waste dumps and/or tailings.
Students must also discuss engineering geology aspects of mine-access infrastructure construction and maintenance and outline a risk assessment for site hazards (e.g., seismicity).
Finally, lessons learned for site characterization, design, and operations should be outlined.
A 1-letter-sized-page, single-sided, handwritten cheat sheet will be allowed during the term test.

The purpose of the project is to demonstrate students' abilities to practise in a geological engineering capacity in their chosen area of expertise, using knowledge gained from their academic and employment experiences.
A basic requirement of the proposed solution is that it must be compatible with the principles of sustainability.
Introduction
Design Process
Alternative Evaluation
Progress Meeting Expectations
Sustainability considerations must be central to the proposed project.
While research (i.e., discovery of new knowledge) may be an important component of engineering design, research-only projects are not appropriate for Engineering Capstone Design Projects.
A five-person team will require a special plan to do more work than the normal four person teams.
Each design team will choose an appropriate Environmental/Geological engineering problem that reflects the interests of the team members.
Teams must select a challenging design problem.
A challenging problem is one where you have few, if any, alternative designs in mind to start the project.
Outstanding grades are possible even if you can’t demonstrate clear innovation in the projects.
Teams must demonstrate that a range of design alternatives were considered.
Teams must quantitatively evaluate multiple alternatives and multiple design objectives/constraints (e.g., engineering analysis and engineering decision-making).

The theory of rates of interest and discount; annuities and sinking funds with practical applications to mortgage and bond questions.
This course provides foundational tools for understanding key financial concepts, such as interest rates, annuities, loans, and bonds.

The principles introduced are essential for performing calculations related to everyday financial matters, like determining mortgage payments or valuing investments, and they play a key role in sectors like banking, insurance, and real estate.

topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.

course_name: MATH228 - Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry (0.50)
major_name: Materials and Nanosciences (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry Winter 2025
First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients, series solutions and special functions, the Laplace transform method.
Applications in physics and chemistry are emphasized.
Differential equations capture how some variable of interest, such as the position of a planet, changes as a function of some independent variable, such as time.
Differential equations are very widely used in the sciences because of the broad range of real-world phenomena they can describe in a mathematical framework.

In this course, students will be introduced to the universe of differential equations, including first-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, the Laplace transform method, and both exact and numerical methods for solving differential equations.
Applications in physics and chemistry will be emphasized.
understand how differential equations can be used to model physical systems,
know how to classify differential equations,
know how to solve various classes of differential equations using numerical methods and exact methods, and

Physically predict, and mathematically model, the outcome(s) after measuring a quantum system
Understand and model the difference between a single measurement outcome and an ensemble average
Predict the time dependence of a quantum system, given its initial state and Hamiltonian
Use commutator identities to check commutation relations for operators
Write the position and momentum operators in terms of the harmonic oscillator ladder operators, and vice versa
State the commutation relations that define a set of angular momentum operators
State the spectrum (allowed eigenvalues) of the angular momentum operators 𝐽^2 and 𝐽_𝑧, in terms of quantum numbers 𝑗 and 𝑚
State the restrictions on the 𝐽^2 and 𝐽_𝑧 eigenvalues, in terms of restrictions on their associated quantum numbers 𝑗 and 𝑚
State the effect of all angular momentum operators on the joint eigenstates of 𝐽^2 and 𝐽_𝑧
Compute the matrix representations of the angular momentum operators for a given 𝑗, in the joint eigenbasis of 𝐽^2 and 𝐽_𝑧
Describe the eigenfunctions of orbital angular momentum (spherical harmonics) in the position basis
For systems with “central” potentials (those that depend only on a radial coordinate), describe the decomposition of the energy eigenfunctions into their angular and radial components
Describe the energies and eigenstates of the hydrogen atom
Describe the degeneracy of different energy eigenstates of the hydrogen atom
State two possible complete sets of mutually commuting operators (CSCOs) whose eigenstates can be used as bases to describe a set of two angular momenta
State the eigenvalues of the CSCOs used to describe a set of two angular momenta
State the selection rules for the Clebsch-Gordan coefficients that relate the coupled and uncoupled bases of a system with two angular momenta
Calculate perturbative energy shifts and wavefunction changes for nondegenerate systems
Calculate perturbative energy shifts for degenerate systems, selecting an appropriate basis for the calculation
Use the variational method to estimate the ground-state energies of simple one-dimensional problems, given a suitable trial function
State the definition of a boson and a fermion, in terms of the spin of the particles
State the symmetry properties of bosonic and fermionic wavefunctions

topics: Modeling Biological Physics Fall 2024
Introduction to modelling living systems and their components.
Statistical methods in data analysis, curve fitting, including p values.
Fourier series and transforms, structural analysis, including nearest neighbour distributions in biomedical applications.
Introduction to methods for analysis of transport properties in biological systems.
Use of computers in these areas.
This course will equip students with basic tools/concepts for analyzing and interpreting data as well as for statistical inference (e.g., p-values).
Molecular diffusion and related equations will be introduced; the ‘Nernst potential’ will be discussed as an example.
Students will learn how ‘Fourier’ methods can be used in experimental biophysics (e.g., spectroscopy).

topics: Review of time-independent perturbation theory (degenerate and non-degenerate, Rayleigh-Schrodinger, Brillouin-Wigner and canonical perturbation theory; effective Hamiltonian derivation).
Second quantization of electromagnetic field in free space; photons.
Introduction to the Dirac equation.
This course will start with a review of the most important concepts from the two previous quantum mechanics courses.
In the next part, we will have an in-depth look at rotations and quantum spin systems.
We will also cover symmetries in quantum mechanics.
In this context, we will for example see how the momentum operator p acts as generator for translations in space, and how angular momentum operators act as generators for rotations.

We will also study discrete symmetries such as the parity symmetry, which leads us to the concept of identical particles, the distinction between Fermions and Bosons, and the puzzling consequences of quantum statistics.
Ability to apply quantum mechanical concepts in a variety of different settings.
Understanding of quantum spin systems and application of the concepts involved (e.g. addition of angular momentum).
Ability to do calculations for spin 1/2 systems and spin 1 systems with ease.
Understanding of continuous & discrete symmetries in quantum mechanics and understanding of the connection between symmetries and conserved quantities.

topics: Introductory Financial Mathematics Winter 2025
Indicate what you've tried and where you're stuck (e.g., "I thought the solution should be ...
The theory of rates of interest and discount; annuities and sinking funds with practical applications to mortgage and bond questions.
This course provides foundational tools for understanding key financial concepts, such as interest rates, annuities, loans, and bonds.

The principles introduced are essential for performing calculations related to everyday financial matters, like determining mortgage payments or valuing investments, and they play a key role in sectors like banking, insurance, and real estate.

By the end of the course, you will have a strong grasp of the mathematical techniques used to approach real-world financial problems, laying a foundation for further study and practical applications in finance and actuarial science.
You can find the Actuarial Science program and plan requirements in the Undergraduate Academic Calendar.

course_name: ACTSC372 - Investment Science and Corporate Finance (0.50)
major_name: Mathematical Finance (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Monitor discussions & respond to questions on Piazza.
Introduction to financial markets.
Rigorous derivations of Markowitz portfolio optimization and its application in investment decisions.
Introduction to options, forwards, and swaps.
This course provides a comprehensive introduction to capital markets, investment principles, and financial decision-making.
The course also examines behavioral finance and the limitations of financial models, offering a balanced perspective on modern finance.
Understand the structure and functioning of capital markets and evaluate risk-return trade-offs in investment decisions.
Apply mean-variance optimization to construct efficient portfolios and analyze risk-return trade-offs.
Utilize Arbitrage Pricing Theory (APT) to identify and assess multiple risk factors influencing asset returns.
Understand and apply the Modigliani-Miller (MM) propositions to assess capital structure decisions in perfect markets.
Explain put-call parity and its role in pricing options and identifying arbitrage opportunities.
Analyze the impact of behavioral biases on investor decision-making and market outcomes.
Evaluate the limitations of financial models and theories in real-world applications.

Investment Rules & Capital Budgeting

Midterm locations are MC 1085 & EIT 1015.

major_name: Mathematical Finance (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Mathematics of Financial Markets Fall 2023
This course covers mathematical techniques for no-arbitrage pricing and hedging financial derivatives.

Topics to be covered can be classified into three broad areas: derivatives markets (options; forwards and futures; other derivatives; put-call parity), discrete-time financial models (binomial models; general multi-period models; Fundamental Theorems of Asset Pricing; risk-neutral probability), and continuous-time financial models (basic stochastic calculus and Itô's lemma; Black-Scholes model; interest rate models and bond pricing).

major_name: Mathematical Finance (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Mathematical Statistics Winter 2025
This course provides a mathematically rigorous treatment for topics covered in STAT230 and 231, and to make essential extensions to the multivariate case.

Topics covered include independence of random variables, conditional expectation and the determination of the distribution of functions of random variables using the cumulative distribution method, change of variable and moment generating functions.
Asymptotic properties of the maximum likelihood estimator are examined and used to construct confidence intervals or regions.
Tutorial: tutorials will be used for going over solutions of practice problem sets and holding term tests.
Have a deep understanding of various mathematical aspects of Statistics and Probability.

The theory of rates of interest and discount; annuities and sinking funds with practical applications to mortgage and bond questions.
This course provides foundational tools for understanding key financial concepts, such as interest rates, annuities, loans, and bonds.

The principles introduced are essential for performing calculations related to everyday financial matters, like determining mortgage payments or valuing investments, and they play a key role in sectors like banking, insurance, and real estate.

By the end of the course, you will have a strong grasp of the mathematical techniques used to approach real-world financial problems, laying a foundation for further study and practical applications in finance and actuarial science.
You can find the Actuarial Science program and plan requirements in the Undergraduate Academic Calendar.
This course meets several requirements for SOA, CAS, and CIA designations
It covers most SOA FM Exam learning objectives, except interest rate swaps and determinants of interest rates.

topics: Songmin Xu s83xu@uwaterloo.ca
Mastering Physics technical support: https://support.pearson.com/getsupport/s/
This is a fast-paced survey course (covering about one textbook chapter per week) introducing a wide range of topics in modern physics.

The intention is four-fold: (1) to make first-year physics more interesting; (2) to provide important, intuitive understanding of key modern physics concepts before your more mathematically rigorous courses in second year; (3) to help you decide which areas of physics you may wish to explore in more depth in upper-year electives; and (4) to have at least a brief introduction to important branches of physics you may not explore further in your degree.
Apply Newton's second law and Newton's law of universal gravitation to solve basic problems in gravitational physics.
Understand, distinguish between and correctly use the concepts of weight, weightlessness, and apparent weight.
Solve simple problems in orbital motion and apply Kepler's three laws.

Properly understand Einstein's two postulates and logically derive from them, and apply, the concepts of time dilation, length contraction, Doppler shift, velocity composition, relativity of simultaneity, and understand why special relativity works for both wave-in-ether and particle-in-vacuum models of light..
Articulate the basic, intuitive ideas of how Einstein's geometrical model of gravity works (equivalence principle and curved spacetime).
Appreciate that classical physics cannot explain the single or double slit experiments.
Understand and predict basic properties of the quantum hydrogen atom based on only the de Broglie relation and classical properties of electron orbits.
Understand the basic idea of a complex number, and in particular, a complex exponential wave, and use it to "derive" the Schrodinger equation.
Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate ionic bonds, covalent bonds, van der Waals bonds, and basic molecular spectra.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate the basic features of atomic nuclei, including nuclear binding energy, nuclear models, nuclear stability and radioactivity, nuclear reactions, nuclear fission, and nuclear fusion.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate some basic aspects of collider physics, including the concept of available energy, and an introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics.

This course will start with a review of the most important concepts from the two previous quantum mechanics courses.
In the next part, we will have an in-depth look at rotations and quantum spin systems.
We will also cover symmetries in quantum mechanics.
In this context, we will for example see how the momentum operator p acts as generator for translations in space, and how angular momentum operators act as generators for rotations.

We will also study discrete symmetries such as the parity symmetry, which leads us to the concept of identical particles, the distinction between Fermions and Bosons, and the puzzling consequences of quantum statistics.
Ability to apply quantum mechanical concepts in a variety of different settings.
Understanding of quantum spin systems and application of the concepts involved (e.g. addition of angular momentum).
Ability to do calculations for spin 1/2 systems and spin 1 systems with ease.
Understanding of continuous & discrete symmetries in quantum mechanics and understanding of the connection between symmetries and conserved quantities.

topics: Applied Linear Algebra 1 Winter 2025
Systems of linear equations.
Introduction to vector spaces.
We will see how to solve systems of linear equations using matrix methods before studying matrices as algebraic objects in their own right.
Next, we will learn about the fundamental concepts of span, linear independence, and basis and learn how to determine whether a set is a subspace of Rn.
After studying subspaces, we will study linear mappings, which map subspaces to subspaces.
We will discuss the geometric interpretation of these mappings and study their fundamental subspaces.
Finally, we will learn how to calculate the determinant of a matrix and use this knowledge to diagonalize square matrices.

major_name: Mathematical Studies (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Linear Algebra 1 (Advanced Level)
Email: karigiannis@uwaterloo.ca
This course is a rigorous treatment of the theory of finite dimensional vector spaces over an arbitrary field.
We also cover the theory of determinants over an arbitrary commutative ring with identity, and some aspects of the theory of polynomials in one variable over a field.

The ultimate goal is the Primary Decomposition Theorem, which characterizes a linear operator on a finite dimensional vector space in terms of invariant subspaces annihilated by the primary factors of its minimal polynomial.
We will cover a large amount of difficult material at a fast pace.
Understand and apply the concepts of the theory of abstract vector spaces and linear operators on finite-dimensional vector spaces.
fields; systems of linear equations; matrices; row-reduced echelon form; matrix algebra; invertible matrices
vector spaces; subspaces; bases and dimension; coordinates; row equivalence
algebra of linear maps; isomorphism; representations by matrices; dual space; transpose of a linear map
commutative rings; existence and uniqueness of determinants; multilinear maps; the exterior algebra
eigenvalues; annihilating polynomials; invariant subspaces; simultaneous triangulation and diagonalization
Much (but not all) of my lectures will closely follow the first six chapters of this book:
“Linear Algebra: Second Edition” by Kenneth Hoffman and Ray Kunze; Prentice Hall, 1971.
“Linear Algebra: Fourth Edition” by Friedberg, Insel, and Spence; Prentice-Hall, 2003.

major_name: Mathematical Studies (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Applied Linear Algebra 2 Winter 2025
Student Drop-In Hours
Getting study ideas
Linear transformations and matrices.
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
In this course, we will learn certain advanced topics in linear algebra.

It turns out that the term “vector space” applies not only to the n-dimensional real vector space Rn, but also to collections of m-by-n matrices with real coefficients Mmxn(R) and polynomials of bounded degree PnR. We will see that such familiar terms as the dot product, norm, distance, orthogonality, and projection can be generalized in a natural way to these vector spaces.
We will also extend the theory of matrix diagonalization to these new settings.
The course will also touch upon some topics that find many real-world applications, such as the Method of Least Squares, Singular Value Decomposition and Linear Programming.
Determine whether a linear mapping between vector spaces is an isomorphism.
Diagonalize a linear mapping.
Use the Fundamental Theorem of Linear Algebra to prove that the rowspace and the columnspace of a matrix are orthogonal to each other.
Determine the best fitting polynomial for a collection of data points using the Method of Least Squares.
Orthogonally diagonalize a symmetric matrix.
Compute a Singular Value Decomposition of a matrix.
Solve constrained optimization problems related to quadratic forms and linear mappings.
Solve constrained optimization problems using linear programming.

major_name: Mathematics (Bachelor of Mathematics, Three-Year General)
topics: Applied Linear Algebra 1 Winter 2025
Systems of linear equations.
Introduction to vector spaces.
We will see how to solve systems of linear equations using matrix methods before studying matrices as algebraic objects in their own right.
Next, we will learn about the fundamental concepts of span, linear independence, and basis and learn how to determine whether a set is a subspace of Rn.
After studying subspaces, we will study linear mappings, which map subspaces to subspaces.
We will discuss the geometric interpretation of these mappings and study their fundamental subspaces.
Finally, we will learn how to calculate the determinant of a matrix and use this knowledge to diagonalize square matrices.
Provide a graphical and algebraic description of vectors, lines, and planes in R^n
Model and solve mathematical and discipline-specific problems using systems of linear equations
Perform basic algebraic operations on matrices
Given a set of vectors in R^n, determine whether it is linearly independent, a spanning set of R^n, or a basis of R^n
Given a basis and a vector in standard coordinates, use matrix methods to calculate its coordinate vectors
Given a set in R^n, determine whether it is a subspace of R^n
Given a mapping L: R^n --> R^m, determine whether it is linear
Given a linear mapping, choose the appropriate algorithm find a basis for each of its fundamental subspaces
Given a square matrix, calculate its determinant and provide a geometric interpretation of this value
Communicate ideas and concepts relating to linear algebra using accurate mathematical language and notation

major_name: Mathematics (Bachelor of Mathematics, Three-Year General)
topics: Linear Algebra 1 (Advanced Level)
Email: karigiannis@uwaterloo.ca
This course is a rigorous treatment of the theory of finite dimensional vector spaces over an arbitrary field.
We also cover the theory of determinants over an arbitrary commutative ring with identity, and some aspects of the theory of polynomials in one variable over a field.

The ultimate goal is the Primary Decomposition Theorem, which characterizes a linear operator on a finite dimensional vector space in terms of invariant subspaces annihilated by the primary factors of its minimal polynomial.
We will cover a large amount of difficult material at a fast pace.
Understand and apply the concepts of the theory of abstract vector spaces and linear operators on finite-dimensional vector spaces.
fields; systems of linear equations; matrices; row-reduced echelon form; matrix algebra; invertible matrices
vector spaces; subspaces; bases and dimension; coordinates; row equivalence
algebra of linear maps; isomorphism; representations by matrices; dual space; transpose of a linear map
commutative rings; existence and uniqueness of determinants; multilinear maps; the exterior algebra
eigenvalues; annihilating polynomials; invariant subspaces; simultaneous triangulation and diagonalization
Much (but not all) of my lectures will closely follow the first six chapters of this book:
“Linear Algebra: Second Edition” by Kenneth Hoffman and Ray Kunze; Prentice Hall, 1971.
“Linear Algebra: Fourth Edition” by Friedberg, Insel, and Spence; Prentice-Hall, 2003.
The assignments are an integral part of your evaluation in this course and I encourage everyone to take them very seriously.
There will be no opportunity for a make-up midterm test.

topics: Applied Linear Algebra 2 Winter 2025
Student Drop-In Hours
Getting study ideas
Linear transformations and matrices.
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
In this course, we will learn certain advanced topics in linear algebra.

It turns out that the term “vector space” applies not only to the n-dimensional real vector space Rn, but also to collections of m-by-n matrices with real coefficients Mmxn(R) and polynomials of bounded degree PnR. We will see that such familiar terms as the dot product, norm, distance, orthogonality, and projection can be generalized in a natural way to these vector spaces.
We will also extend the theory of matrix diagonalization to these new settings.
The course will also touch upon some topics that find many real-world applications, such as the Method of Least Squares, Singular Value Decomposition and Linear Programming.
Determine whether a linear mapping between vector spaces is an isomorphism.

Orthogonally diagonalize a symmetric matrix.
Compute a Singular Value Decomposition of a matrix.
Solve constrained optimization problems related to quadratic forms and linear mappings.
Solve constrained optimization problems using linear programming.

major_name: Mathematics (Joint Honours)
topics: Applied Linear Algebra 1 Winter 2025
Systems of linear equations.
Introduction to vector spaces.
We will see how to solve systems of linear equations using matrix methods before studying matrices as algebraic objects in their own right.
Next, we will learn about the fundamental concepts of span, linear independence, and basis and learn how to determine whether a set is a subspace of Rn.
After studying subspaces, we will study linear mappings, which map subspaces to subspaces.
We will discuss the geometric interpretation of these mappings and study their fundamental subspaces.
Finally, we will learn how to calculate the determinant of a matrix and use this knowledge to diagonalize square matrices.
Provide a graphical and algebraic description of vectors, lines, and planes in R^n
Model and solve mathematical and discipline-specific problems using systems of linear equations
Perform basic algebraic operations on matrices
Given a set of vectors in R^n, determine whether it is linearly independent, a spanning set of R^n, or a basis of R^n
Given a basis and a vector in standard coordinates, use matrix methods to calculate its coordinate vectors
Given a set in R^n, determine whether it is a subspace of R^n
Given a mapping L: R^n --> R^m, determine whether it is linear
Given a linear mapping, choose the appropriate algorithm find a basis for each of its fundamental subspaces
Given a square matrix, calculate its determinant and provide a geometric interpretation of this value
Communicate ideas and concepts relating to linear algebra using accurate mathematical language and notation

major_name: Mathematics (Joint Honours)
topics: Linear Algebra 1 (Advanced Level)
Email: karigiannis@uwaterloo.ca
This course is a rigorous treatment of the theory of finite dimensional vector spaces over an arbitrary field.
We also cover the theory of determinants over an arbitrary commutative ring with identity, and some aspects of the theory of polynomials in one variable over a field.

The ultimate goal is the Primary Decomposition Theorem, which characterizes a linear operator on a finite dimensional vector space in terms of invariant subspaces annihilated by the primary factors of its minimal polynomial.
We will cover a large amount of difficult material at a fast pace.
Understand and apply the concepts of the theory of abstract vector spaces and linear operators on finite-dimensional vector spaces.
fields; systems of linear equations; matrices; row-reduced echelon form; matrix algebra; invertible matrices
vector spaces; subspaces; bases and dimension; coordinates; row equivalence
algebra of linear maps; isomorphism; representations by matrices; dual space; transpose of a linear map
commutative rings; existence and uniqueness of determinants; multilinear maps; the exterior algebra
eigenvalues; annihilating polynomials; invariant subspaces; simultaneous triangulation and diagonalization
Much (but not all) of my lectures will closely follow the first six chapters of this book:
“Linear Algebra: Second Edition” by Kenneth Hoffman and Ray Kunze; Prentice Hall, 1971.
“Linear Algebra: Fourth Edition” by Friedberg, Insel, and Spence; Prentice-Hall, 2003.
The assignments are an integral part of your evaluation in this course and I encourage everyone to take them very seriously.

Next, we will learn about the fundamental concepts of span, linear independence, and basis and learn how to determine whether a set is a subspace of Rn.
After studying subspaces, we will study linear mappings, which map subspaces to subspaces.
We will discuss the geometric interpretation of these mappings and study their fundamental subspaces.
Finally, we will learn how to calculate the determinant of a matrix and use this knowledge to diagonalize square matrices.
Provide a graphical and algebraic description of vectors, lines, and planes in R^n
Model and solve mathematical and discipline-specific problems using systems of linear equations
Perform basic algebraic operations on matrices

Given a mapping L: R^n --> R^m, determine whether it is linear
Given a linear mapping, choose the appropriate algorithm find a basis for each of its fundamental subspaces

This course provides foundational tools for understanding key financial concepts, such as interest rates, annuities, loans, and bonds.

The principles introduced are essential for performing calculations related to everyday financial matters, like determining mortgage payments or valuing investments, and they play a key role in sectors like banking, insurance, and real estate.

By the end of the course, you will have a strong grasp of the mathematical techniques used to approach real-world financial problems, laying a foundation for further study and practical applications in finance and actuarial science.

course_name: AMATH343 - Discrete Models in Applied Mathematics (0.50)
major_name: Mathematics/Teaching (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Discrete Models in Applied Mathematics Fall 2023
Difference equations and discrete dynamical systems.
Mathematical models are taken from ecology, biology, economics, and other fields.

Many such systems evolve over continuous time and can be modelled by differential equations, however, there are some systems for which the evolution is more appropriately described using discrete time intervals - for example, plant and animal populations where breeding and other effects can be assumed to take place at particular times of the year.
As with differential equations, difference equations can be classified as linear difference equations and nonlinear difference equations.
First, we will examine linear difference equations and a number of standard methods to solve them.
The asymptotic behaviour of nonlinear systems can be quite complicated, leading to such things as “bifurcations,” “chaos,” and “fractals.”
A few simple models will be studied in order to understand certain aspects of this behaviour.
We will explore the notion of “fractal dimension” as well as some simple methods of generating fractal sets.
Time permitting, we will look at iterated function systems (IFS), a simple, yet powerful, geometric method of generating and studying fractal sets.

major_name: Mathematics/Chartered Professional Accountancy (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Linear Algebra 1 (Advanced Level)
Email: karigiannis@uwaterloo.ca
This course is a rigorous treatment of the theory of finite dimensional vector spaces over an arbitrary field.
We also cover the theory of determinants over an arbitrary commutative ring with identity, and some aspects of the theory of polynomials in one variable over a field.

The ultimate goal is the Primary Decomposition Theorem, which characterizes a linear operator on a finite dimensional vector space in terms of invariant subspaces annihilated by the primary factors of its minimal polynomial.
We will cover a large amount of difficult material at a fast pace.
Understand and apply the concepts of the theory of abstract vector spaces and linear operators on finite-dimensional vector spaces.
fields; systems of linear equations; matrices; row-reduced echelon form; matrix algebra; invertible matrices
vector spaces; subspaces; bases and dimension; coordinates; row equivalence
algebra of linear maps; isomorphism; representations by matrices; dual space; transpose of a linear map
commutative rings; existence and uniqueness of determinants; multilinear maps; the exterior algebra
eigenvalues; annihilating polynomials; invariant subspaces; simultaneous triangulation and diagonalization
Much (but not all) of my lectures will closely follow the first six chapters of this book:
“Linear Algebra: Second Edition” by Kenneth Hoffman and Ray Kunze; Prentice Hall, 1971.
“Linear Algebra: Fourth Edition” by Friedberg, Insel, and Spence; Prentice-Hall, 2003.
The assignments are an integral part of your evaluation in this course and I encourage everyone to take them very seriously.

The theory of rates of interest and discount; annuities and sinking funds with practical applications to mortgage and bond questions.
This course provides foundational tools for understanding key financial concepts, such as interest rates, annuities, loans, and bonds.

The principles introduced are essential for performing calculations related to everyday financial matters, like determining mortgage payments or valuing investments, and they play a key role in sectors like banking, insurance, and real estate.

By the end of the course, you will have a strong grasp of the mathematical techniques used to approach real-world financial problems, laying a foundation for further study and practical applications in finance and actuarial science.

course_name: ACTSC372 - Investment Science and Corporate Finance (0.50)
major_name: Mathematics/Financial Analysis and Risk Management - Chartered Financial Analyst Specialization (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Monitor discussions & respond to questions on Piazza.
Introduction to financial markets.
Rigorous derivations of Markowitz portfolio optimization and its application in investment decisions.
Introduction to options, forwards, and swaps.
This course provides a comprehensive introduction to capital markets, investment principles, and financial decision-making.
The course also examines behavioral finance and the limitations of financial models, offering a balanced perspective on modern finance.
Understand the structure and functioning of capital markets and evaluate risk-return trade-offs in investment decisions.
Apply mean-variance optimization to construct efficient portfolios and analyze risk-return trade-offs.
Utilize Arbitrage Pricing Theory (APT) to identify and assess multiple risk factors influencing asset returns.
Understand and apply the Modigliani-Miller (MM) propositions to assess capital structure decisions in perfect markets.
Explain put-call parity and its role in pricing options and identifying arbitrage opportunities.
Analyze the impact of behavioral biases on investor decision-making and market outcomes.
Evaluate the limitations of financial models and theories in real-world applications.
Course Intro & Overview of Financial Markets
Investment Rules & Capital Budgeting
Mean-variance optimization
CAPM & Arbitrage pricing theory (APT)
Dividend policy & Introduction to options
Option Pricing & Expected utility theory
Behavioral finance & course review.
Midterm locations are MC 1085 & EIT 1015.

major_name: Mathematics/Financial Analysis and Risk Management - Chartered Financial Analyst Specialization (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Mathematics of Financial Markets Fall 2023
This course covers mathematical techniques for no-arbitrage pricing and hedging financial derivatives.

Topics to be covered can be classified into three broad areas: derivatives markets (options; forwards and futures; other derivatives; put-call parity), discrete-time financial models (binomial models; general multi-period models; Fundamental Theorems of Asset Pricing; risk-neutral probability), and continuous-time financial models (basic stochastic calculus and Itô's lemma; Black-Scholes model; interest rate models and bond pricing).

This course covers mathematical techniques for no-arbitrage pricing and hedging financial derivatives.

Topics to be covered can be classified into three broad areas: derivatives markets (options; forwards and futures; other derivatives; put-call parity), discrete-time financial models (binomial models; general multi-period models; Fundamental Theorems of Asset Pricing; risk-neutral probability), and continuous-time financial models (basic stochastic calculus and Itô's lemma; Black-Scholes model; interest rate models and bond pricing).

topics: Mathematical Statistics Winter 2025
This course provides a mathematically rigorous treatment for topics covered in STAT230 and 231, and to make essential extensions to the multivariate case.

Topics covered include independence of random variables, conditional expectation and the determination of the distribution of functions of random variables using the cumulative distribution method, change of variable and moment generating functions.
Asymptotic properties of the maximum likelihood estimator are examined and used to construct confidence intervals or regions.

Each team is required to design, build, test, and verify the performance of a powered mechanism to move multiple objects from a storage area onto a raised conveyor belt to deliver to a drop-off area.
Move 2 objects (one from red, one from blue) from the storage area to the drop-off area of the corresponding colour
Other objects can be used to demonstrate certain design objectives have been achieved
Demonstrate how your design meets your selected Design Objectives and Engineering Specifications
Energy must be supplied to the system using provided electrical power source(s) or a separate used console
Pick-up and drop-off areas cannot be manipulated to assist with object pick-up or placement*
Possible Design Objectives:
Possible Design Objectives:
Design for speed to move 2+ objects
Design for accuracy/precision of object placement or storage in drop-off area
Design for strength-weight ratio to lift and move heavier objects
Design for efficiency to minimize the amount of energy or work required
Design for range of motion to pick up objects from multiple storage areas
Design for dexterity to place objects on the conveyor in different orientations
Design for compliance to pick up difficult to grasp objects (beyond the baseline 3DBenchy)
Design for smooth operation (e.g. minimize jerkiness)
Design for adaptability to handle variable storage area conditions (e.g. mixed objects)

Project Scope: The individual design criterion and demonstration methods for the selected design objective are intended to be open-ended and up to the team to propose to the “client” (instructor and TAs).
In general, the overall structure of the project should follow:
Identify the design need, define design requirements, and develop design specifications
Generate and assess design concepts
Embodiment and detailed design
Verify that the design meets the requirements

topics: Mechanical Engineering Design Project 1 Fall 2024
Role and responsibilities:
Role and responsibilities:
The first of two required courses for the mechanical engineering capstone design project.

This course is intended to enable students to engage in in-depth engineering design and decision-making using engineering science while encouraging creativity and resourcefulness, and addressing the criteria listed in the faculty of engineering design rubrics.
The goal is to develop a design proposal, consisting of the needs analysis, design specifications and project plan, followed by the initial and detailed design work.
While research (i.e. discovery of new knowledge) is an important part of a design project methodology, research-only projects are not appropriate for this course sequence.
Identify, represent and communicate a mechanical engineering problem or opportunity [
Design a mechanical engineering system, product and/or process [
Design review presentations   Monday – Friday, Nov. 25 – 29  TBA
The following items should be kept in mind when you are choosing your project:
A normal team size is 4 students; exceptions can be made by the course instructor given adequate justification.
The topic is based in the field of mechanical engineering
The problem is open-ended and has sufficient scope and complexity to provide a significant challenge
The analysis required to complete the project makes use of mechanical engineering knowledge and skills
Industry-based collaborative projects are welcome.
Proposal – During the fourth week of the term each team will submit a written project proposal that includes the following information:
Needs analysis, including requirements, constraints and/or criteria, captured in the form of a revision-controlled engineering design specification document.
Requirements should be expressed as values wherever possible, with justification provided.
Organization chart of team, including roles
Work breakdown structure, including estimated number of hours for each task
Project schedule, including key milestones
Estimated project cost and expected sources of funding
Identified risks and mitigation plans
Change management implementation strategy and examples
Evaluation of your design decisions based on the decision criteria presented in proposal
Presentations must be kept within the time specified and should include information intended for a technical audience who is not familiar with the project.
This grade will be based on the team charter, and a survey conducted at the end of the term to assess the contribution of each member to the team.
Financial Support for Projects – The Mechanical and Mechatronics Department supports design projects to a maximum of $75 per student per term, or $150 per student for both ME481 and ME482 combined.

This course provides a framework for understanding professionalism and ethics within society as reflected through practice in the field of professional engineering.

Course topics on professionalism include the history of engineering and professions, the licensing of professional engineers and the certification of the practice of offering engineering services to the public, and the regulation of professional engineering in Ontario through Professional Engineers Ontario.

major_name: Mechanical Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Fundamentals in Neural and Rehabilitation Engineering Fall 2024
DWE 2402
DWE 2402
DWE 2402
DWE 2402
DWE 2402
Introduction to the field of neural and rehabilitation engineering (NRE).

Topics include describing common neurological and musculoskeletal injuries, related neural and rehabilitation engineering approaches to address disabilities, and the development of a design framework for synthesizing a novel neural and rehabilitation engineering approach.
Critical concepts in clinical research design to meet current regulatory, ethical, and practice policies will be studied.
Describe and apply evidence-based medicine (EBM) concepts applied to NRE.
Evaluate and criticize existing neural and rehabilitation engineering (NRE) approaches.
Synthesize and disseminate a novel innovation to solve a self-selected problem in NRE.
There are 12 graduate attributes total and collection of these attributes is pertinent in ensuring our engineering programs remain accredited.
This is an upper year elective course introducing the field of neural and rehabilitation engineering (NRE) by exposing students to the key problems and current engineering approaches.
The first half of the course will focus on describing common neurological and musculoskeletal injuries and related NRE approaches to address disabilities.
Subsequent classes will examine critical concepts in clinical research design to meet current regulatory, ethical, and practice policies.
At the end of the term, students will pitch their proposal to a panel of judges, representing clinical and industry stakeholders.

Hands-on labs will teach students the integration of mechanical, electrical, and software systems through building a soft robotic finger prosthesis along with inertial measurement units, electromyography and electroencephalography.

A course to develop the understanding required to simulate complex fluid flows, such as those found in turbo-machines, duct systems, and other engineering hardware.

Course topics include the physics of complex viscous fluid flows, first- and second-order finite control volume discretization methods, iterative algorithms for the solution of sparse matrix equation sets, including multi-grid acceleration, boundary condition modelling, two-equation and Reynolds stress turbulence models, and grid generation techniques.
Computational fluid dynamics software is used throughout the course to simulate and analyze complex fluid flows relevant to engineering applications.

Course Introduction An introduction to the teaching team, course expectations, deliverables, marking scheme, and a very brief introduction to interfacing concepts.
Embedded Systems A review of fundamentals of embedded systems and the terminology associated with embedded systems.
Embedded Design Model An introduction to the embedded design model used to develop a system for the remainder of the course.
Embedded Software An overview of they key differences between software for embedded systems and general software development.
Synchronization, Data Generation and Data Transfer A model for analyzing synchronization behaviour and performance and examples of synchronization analysis.
Buses - Data Transfer A comparison of the functional behaviour and timing behaviour of synchronous, asynchronous, and partially interlocked asynchronous.
Parallel Interfacing A detailed examination of the design of parallel interfaces.
This includes an examination of the role of the interface in matching bus timing and signaling characteristics with a device's timing and signaling characteristics.
Analog Interfacing An introduction to digital-to-analog interfacing, analog-to-digital interfacing, and sample-and-hold circuitry.
This includes a comparison of asynchronous communication techniques and synchronous techniques as well as the protocols for serial communication.

Buses - Arbitration A brief examination of alternatives for bus arbitration including a discussion of the operation and characteristics of daisy chained and non-daisy chained bus arbitration techniques.
A brief examination of direct memory access including a discussion of hardware design implications, software implications, and system performance.
Security and Ethics An overview of common security terminology and why it has become increasingly important for embedded systems.
The ethical implications of today’s embedded systems applications will also be discussed.

The course will provide an introduction to the research field of social robotics, with a particular human-centered perspective.

Robots that can interact socially in an effective and acceptable manner with people have become increasingly important for applications ranging from robot-assisted therapy for people with special needs, robotic assistants for older people and care home residents, robots as tools in education or robotic co-workers for a new generation of  industrial robot that emphasize human-machine collaboration and communication.

Students will gain an understanding of the concepts and theories underlying social robotics, as well as research methodologies and techniques to realize socially intelligent robots and design, plan and evaluate human-robot interaction experiments.
Understand concepts and theories underlying social robotics
Apply research methodologies and techniques to realize socially intelligent robots
Design, plan, and evaluate human-robot interaction experiments
Demonstrate scientific writing and presentation skills
Explain how psychology and social sciences can inform the engineering of social robots
Understand basic principles of sensors, actuators and multi-model interaction and communication for social robots
Explain examples of robot computational architectures used in human-robot interaction
Definitions of social robots and requirements of robots’ social skill and their relevance to robotics and Artificial Intelligence in real-world applications
The role of affective expressions of social robots and modelling emotions to facilitate human-robot engagement
Evaluating usability, user experience and acceptance of social robots
Guidelines of how to write up social robotics research for a scientific publication
Overview of cognitive architectures for socially intelligent robots
Featuring interdisciplinary research in social robotics based on research from other fields, e.g. from (developmental) psychology, ethology or primatology
Roles of social robots in human society and their potential impact on society and wellbeing
Selected examples of applications of social robots e.g. in care, therapy, education, rehabilitation and co-worker scenarios will be discussed throughout the course
Ethical, safety and privacy issues as relevant to social robotics will be discussed throughout the course
Course Grading for Graduate Students:

20% Individual discussion paper: Students will reflect on work in Science Fiction involving the concepts of social and intelligent robots, and reflect on the relevance to today’s robotics technology in robotics and Artificial Intelligence.
Students can choose the work and discuss the selection with the instructor.

Students are required to write a report that motivates, describes and discusses those behaviours in light of the state of the art literature, and describe an experimental design for a human-robot interaction experiment where those behaviours could be tested and analyzed.

Specifically, students’ reports will be evaluated based on a) the literature review demonstrating the level of knowledge in this domain, b) the relevance of the identified research questions and hypotheses, c) the depth of the proposed research program, d) the range, complexity and quality of the implemented and documented robot behaviours, e) the detailed description of the methodology used to carry out and analyze this program of work, f) the user study conducted and how results are presented and analysed, and finally, g) a critical evaluation of possible limitations of the expected outcomes and backup plans in order to address  possible delays and technical difficulties encountered during the implementation of the work.
Note, those skills can also be applied to related fields of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI), Human Factors etc.

20% Individual discussion paper: Students will reflect on work in Science Fiction involving the concepts of social and intelligent robots, and reflect on the relevance to today’s robotics technology in robotics and Artificial Intelligence.
Students can choose the work and discuss the selection with the instructor.

Students are required to write a report that motivates, describes and discusses those behaviours in light of the state of the art literature, and describe a possible experimental design for a human-robot interaction experiment where those implemented behaviours could be tested and analyzed.

topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);

course_name: NE112 - Linear Algebra for Nanotechnology Engineers (0.50)
major_name: Nanotechnology Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Linear Algebra for Nanotechnology Engineers Fall 2024
Solution of linear equations: elimination and iterative methods.
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors with engineering applications.

Prerequisite knowledge: Secondary school mathematics, including real numbers, 2d- and 3d-vectors, the Euclidean norm, dot products and right angles between vectors, matrices, solving systems of linear equations, functions, polynomials, differentiation, sets, set membership, intersection and union.
Describe real and complex vector spaces, both finite and infinite-dimensional.
Understand linear independence and bases.
Solve a system of linear equations, considering the concept of numerical instabilities.
Describe the concept of a singular-value decomposition.
Also, the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering cancels classes during mid-term week and, instead, offers make-up lectures.
Introduction to axioms and complex numbers.
Geometric series, real n-dimensional vectors, the zero vector, geometric interpretations, equality, 2-d vectors vs complex complex n-dimensional vectors and scalar multiplication and vector addition.
Properties of vector spaces, linear combination of vectors, other vector spaces, subspaces, normed vector spaces and inner product spaces.

Inner products on other vector spaces, orthogonality, the Pythagorean theorem, projections, the Cauchy-Bunyakovsky-Schwarz inequality, the Gram-Schmidt algorithm, and finding solutions to systems of linear equations.
A systematic approach to solving systems of linear equations, matrices, augmented matrices, zero rows, leading zeros, leading non-zero entries, row-echelon form, and backward substitution.
Row operations, Gaussian elimination with partial pivoting, solutions to homogeneous systems of linear equations, linear dependence and independence of vectors.

Spans and subspaces, bases and dimension, introduction to linear maps and linear operators, the superposition principle, special linear maps and linear operators, the range and null space of a linear map, and the vector space of linear maps.
The composition of linear maps, linear operators, row operations as linear operators, the determinant, trace and inverse, and matrices of orthonormal vectors and their inverses.

Introduction to matrix decompositions, the PLU decomposition, the adjoint of a linear map, its properties, the transpose, the conjugate transpose, self-adjoint and skew-adjoint linear operators, normal operators, isometric operators, and linear regression and least squares.

An introduction to linear algebra for nanotechnology engineering with applications in Matlab https://ece.uwaterloo.ca/~ne112/Lecture_materials/An%20introduction%20to%20linear%20algebra%20for%20undergraduate%20engineering%20with%20applications%20in%20Matlab.pdf Yes

course_name: NE220L - Materials Science and Engineering Laboratory (0.25)
major_name: Nanotechnology Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Arrange for assistance via email
Teaching Assistants Name and Email:
Impact Testing QNC 2613 Maggie Wong m228wong@uwaterloo.ca
Thermal Gravimetric Analysis QNC 2613 Mahsa Barjini Khabbaz mbarjinikhabbaz@uwaterloo.ca

Experimental exercises will study the physical properties and characteristics of materials, including mechanical, thermal, electrical, and structural/morphological properties at different length scales.
Specific samples relevant to a characterization technique are utilized to demonstrate its usefulness.

In addition, analyses of Low-Density Polyethylene (LDPE), High Density Polyethylene (HDPE), HDPE + 10 wt.% Graphene black, and HDPE + 2.5 wt.% Plasticizer are carried out to demonstrate the power of applying multiple characterization techniques to a family of related materials.
A SolidWorks simulation is used to further enhance understanding of characterization.

The set of experiments provided in this laboratory course is intended to introduce the capabilities of each equipment, provide hands-on experience in conducting the experiment and analyzing the data, and demonstrate how to obtain a thorough understanding of the properties of these materials by employing a series of complementary analysis methods.
Apply the reaction rate law and heat capacity expression to demonstrate comprehensive analysis resulted from the complementary characterization techniques.
Develop a comprehensive understanding of material properties in realistic situations.
Topics to be covered in the laboratory periods:
Different polymer samples will be used to demonstrate the capabilities of each instrument.
Although only polymer samples will be tested during this course, it is important to notice that these techniques can be transferrable to other types of solid materials, such as ceramics and metals.
The impact test subjects the material to high-speed deformation.
This exercise also includes converting the polymer from pellet form to moulded bars for impact testing and dogbones for tensile testing using a hot press or an injection moulder.
TGA will also be used to determine the composition of a copolymer and the activation energy of a degradation reaction using the Flynn-Wall-Ozawa method.
The thermal properties of amorphous and semi-crystalline polymers will be analyzed by DSC.

The approximate length of time required for completing the pre-laboratory safety test and completion of the pre-laboratory exercise should not exceed the number of hours that were taken to do the laboratory exercise itself.
Several of the experiments allow sufficient time to complete the laboratory report during the laboratory period and can be submitted before leaving the lab.
Make-up laboratory sessions will generally not be accommodated in the absence of extenuating circumstances as assessed by the Laboratory Instructor or without a valid medical certificate.

major_name: Nanotechnology Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Engineering and Sustainable Development Spring 2024
nadine.ibrahim@uwaterloo.ca
nadine.ibrahim@uwaterloo.ca
This course introduces the concept of sustainability and how it applies to decision-making in civil engineering.
The course begins by defining sustainability, both practically and technically, and describing the concepts of systems, and systems interactions.
Economic concepts and their applicability to sustainability are described for both developed and developing countries.
Sustainability concepts covering the triple bottom line are presented, and their applicability to sustainability are described.
First, the qualitative concepts and background information is presented.
I’ll be teaching sustainable development and its connection to engineering using both a qualitative and quantitative understanding of sustainability.
Qualitatively, this involves describing sustainability objectives, trends, current conditions and future projections, and to have a technical and public understanding of sustainability challenges.

Quantitatively, this involves modeling environmental parameters using linear programming, differential equations, regression and extrapolation, and understanding the metrics used for sustainability assessments.
I believe students have different strengths, where the diversity of coursework will leverage individual strengths and give everybody a chance to shine!
I encourage you to read the announcements on a regular basis and stay up to date.
IDENTIFY: Identify implications of human activities on the three dimensions of sustainability
QUANTIFY: Quantify sustainability indicators to assess trade-offs
DEMONSTRATE: Demonstrate course concepts to assess sustainability in global cities

Graduate Attribute Program Indicators

A knowledge base for engineering: Demonstrated competence in university level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the program.
1a Demonstrate understanding of concepts in mathematics.
1b Demonstrate understanding of concepts in natural science.
1c Demonstrate understanding of engineering fundamentals.
1d Demonstrate understanding of specialized engineering knowledge.
2. Problem Analysis: An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

3. Investigation: An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.
3a Create investigative studies of complex engineering problems.
3b Gather information from relevant sources to address complex engineering problems.

4. Design: An ability to design solutions for complex, open-ended engineering problems and to design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate attention to health and safety risks, applicable standards, economic, environmental, cultural and societal considerations.
4a Define design requirements and specifications for complex, open-ended engineering problems.
4b Critically evaluate and compare design choices.
7. Communication skills: An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.
Professionalism: An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.
8a Articulate the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society with reference to the protection of the public and its interest.
Impact of Engineering: An ability to analyze social and environmental aspects of engineering activities.

Such abilities include an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society; the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.
Analyze the social, health, safety, and environmental aspects of an engineering project, incorporating sustainability considerations and environmental stewardship in making decisions.
10a Identify ethical and unethical behavior in professional situations.
10b Identify how an engineer is accountable to multiple stakeholders in engineering practice.
Life-long Learning: An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world to sufficiently maintain their competence and contribute to the advancement of knowledge.
12a Identify gaps in their knowledge, skills and abilities.

major_name: Nanotechnology Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: For in-person meetings: Please set up via e-mail message
Overview of polymer production technology and polymer reaction engineering analysis tools.

Calculations and mathematical models for rate, copolymer composition, molecular weight and sequence length characteristics, for polymer reactor design/optimization of polymer productivity and quality variables.
View requirements for CHE 543

Be fluent with Polymer Reaction Engineering (PRE) tools (mathematical modelling and reaction engineering tools for understanding/designing/troubleshooting/optimizing polymerization reactors, and for controlling polymer product properties); optimization and control strategies in order to deliver desirable properties for final applications (3b, 3c, 4c, 4c, 5b, 5c)

The idea is to become fluent with polymer reactor aspects and the basic tools of PRE from mathematical modelling in aid of polymerization process (and polymer product) understanding, operation troubleshooting and, finally, optimization/control.

Course Introduction An introduction to the teaching team, course expectations, deliverables, marking scheme, and a very brief introduction to interfacing concepts.
Embedded Systems A review of fundamentals of embedded systems and the terminology associated with embedded systems.
Embedded Design Model An introduction to the embedded design model used to develop a system for the remainder of the course.
Embedded Software An overview of they key differences between software for embedded systems and general software development.
Synchronization, Data Generation and Data Transfer A model for analyzing synchronization behaviour and performance and examples of synchronization analysis.
Buses - Data Transfer A comparison of the functional behaviour and timing behaviour of synchronous, asynchronous, and partially interlocked asynchronous.
Parallel Interfacing A detailed examination of the design of parallel interfaces.
This includes an examination of the role of the interface in matching bus timing and signaling characteristics with a device's timing and signaling characteristics.
Analog Interfacing An introduction to digital-to-analog interfacing, analog-to-digital interfacing, and sample-and-hold circuitry.
This includes a comparison of asynchronous communication techniques and synchronous techniques as well as the protocols for serial communication.

Buses - Arbitration A brief examination of alternatives for bus arbitration including a discussion of the operation and characteristics of daisy chained and non-daisy chained bus arbitration techniques.
A brief examination of direct memory access including a discussion of hardware design implications, software implications, and system performance.
Security and Ethics An overview of common security terminology and why it has become increasingly important for embedded systems.
The ethical implications of today’s embedded systems applications will also be discussed.

A course to develop the understanding required to simulate complex fluid flows, such as those found in turbo-machines, duct systems, and other engineering hardware.

Course topics include the physics of complex viscous fluid flows, first- and second-order finite control volume discretization methods, iterative algorithms for the solution of sparse matrix equation sets, including multi-grid acceleration, boundary condition modelling, two-equation and Reynolds stress turbulence models, and grid generation techniques.
Computational fluid dynamics software is used throughout the course to simulate and analyze complex fluid flows relevant to engineering applications.

Course Introduction An introduction to the teaching team, course expectations, deliverables, marking scheme, and a very brief introduction to interfacing concepts.
Embedded Systems A review of fundamentals of embedded systems and the terminology associated with embedded systems.
Embedded Design Model An introduction to the embedded design model used to develop a system for the remainder of the course.
Embedded Software An overview of they key differences between software for embedded systems and general software development.
Synchronization, Data Generation and Data Transfer A model for analyzing synchronization behaviour and performance and examples of synchronization analysis.
Buses - Data Transfer A comparison of the functional behaviour and timing behaviour of synchronous, asynchronous, and partially interlocked asynchronous.
Parallel Interfacing A detailed examination of the design of parallel interfaces.
This includes an examination of the role of the interface in matching bus timing and signaling characteristics with a device's timing and signaling characteristics.
Analog Interfacing An introduction to digital-to-analog interfacing, analog-to-digital interfacing, and sample-and-hold circuitry.
This includes a comparison of asynchronous communication techniques and synchronous techniques as well as the protocols for serial communication.

Buses - Arbitration A brief examination of alternatives for bus arbitration including a discussion of the operation and characteristics of daisy chained and non-daisy chained bus arbitration techniques.
A brief examination of direct memory access including a discussion of hardware design implications, software implications, and system performance.
Security and Ethics An overview of common security terminology and why it has become increasingly important for embedded systems.
The ethical implications of today’s embedded systems applications will also be discussed.

major_name: Environmental Engineering Option
topics: Engineering and Sustainable Development Spring 2024
nadine.ibrahim@uwaterloo.ca
nadine.ibrahim@uwaterloo.ca
This course introduces the concept of sustainability and how it applies to decision-making in civil engineering.
The course begins by defining sustainability, both practically and technically, and describing the concepts of systems, and systems interactions.
Economic concepts and their applicability to sustainability are described for both developed and developing countries.
Sustainability concepts covering the triple bottom line are presented, and their applicability to sustainability are described.
First, the qualitative concepts and background information is presented.
I’ll be teaching sustainable development and its connection to engineering using both a qualitative and quantitative understanding of sustainability.
Qualitatively, this involves describing sustainability objectives, trends, current conditions and future projections, and to have a technical and public understanding of sustainability challenges.

Quantitatively, this involves modeling environmental parameters using linear programming, differential equations, regression and extrapolation, and understanding the metrics used for sustainability assessments.
I believe students have different strengths, where the diversity of coursework will leverage individual strengths and give everybody a chance to shine!
I encourage you to read the announcements on a regular basis and stay up to date.

Develop and apply a mathematical framework using systems thinking to articulate and analyze decision-making problems in environmental engineering.
Acquire skills to solve decision-making problems using various methods, including decision trees, multi-criteria decision making, and both single and multi-objective optimization.
Gain insights into recognizing and evaluating the uncertainties inherent in decision-making and will learn to apply stochastic optimization techniques in uncertain scenarios.
Broaden their knowledge and interest in advanced decision science methodologies to tackle complex issues in environmental sustainability.

Engineering Biomedical Economics Fall 2024
This course examines key economic issues in health care and biomedical industries.
Topics include the market for medical care, health insurance, various models of healthcare delivery and competition and the role of government in policy, financing and delivery of health care.
This course will train students to use economic analysis to model and understand the complex interactions between health care delivery, insurance markets, health innovators, governments, and firms.
Articulate differences between healthcare systems and how incentives affect the system economics.
Articulate differences between healthcare systems and how incentives affect the system economics.
