A knowledge base for engineering:   Demonstrated competence in university level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the biomedical engineering program.
2. Problem analysis:  An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

Investigation:  An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.

4. Design:  An ability to design solutions for complex, open-ended engineering problems and to design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate attention to health and safety risks, applicable standards, and economic, environmental, cultural and societal considerations.
7. Communication skills:  An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.

Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking and listening, and the ability to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.
Professionalism:   An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.

Such ability includes an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society, the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.

Life-long learning:  An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world in ways sufficient to maintain their competence and to allow them to contribute to the advancement of knowledge.

A course to develop the understanding required to simulate complex fluid flows, such as those found in turbo-machines, duct systems, and other engineering hardware.

Course topics include the physics of complex viscous fluid flows, first- and second-order finite control volume discretization methods, iterative algorithms for the solution of sparse matrix equation sets, including multi-grid acceleration, boundary condition modelling, two-equation and Reynolds stress turbulence models, and grid generation techniques.
Computational fluid dynamics software is used throughout the course to simulate and analyze complex fluid flows relevant to engineering applications.

The course will focus on techniques for building information systems that meet human needs and capabilities by following a system development lifecycle: user requirements analysis, information and interaction design, prototyping and evaluation.
View requirements for MSE 343
Explain and justify the benefits and drawbacks of user-centred design
Describe guidelines and models that can be applied to interface design
Apply a variety of methods to involve the people who use an application in the design process
Evaluate the usability of an interface

Evaluate the usability of an interface 4 Des c) Evaluate/test solutions and refine designs to better meet requirements

major_name: Software Engineering Option
topics: Notice of Recording
Microprocessor Systems and Interfacing for Mechatronics Engineering Winter 2025
book a meeting
Synchronization and data flow; interfacing to sensors and actuators;
parallel, serial, and analog interfacing; buses; direct memory access (DMA); interfacing considerations; privacy and security considerations.
View requirements for MTE 325
Summarize the flow of data between software and hardware elements in an embedded system
Describe the trade-offs between implementation alternatives for both hardware and software
Outline the ethical implications of embedded system design choices
Use industry-standard tools to implement and debug embedded systems
Design an embedded system to perform a given task
Projects provide students with an opportunity to explore selected concepts in a real-world context.
Lectures and tutorials are held in person and attendance is expected at all sessions for learning and skill development.
Jan 20th and Jan 22nd  Lab 1 – Introduction and setup (watch Learn for signup instructions closer to)
Lab 2 – Synchronization Techniques
Course Introduction An introduction to the teaching team, course expectations, deliverables, marking scheme, and a very brief introduction to interfacing concepts.
Embedded Systems A review of fundamentals of embedded systems and the terminology associated with embedded systems.
Embedded Design Model An introduction to the embedded design model used to develop a system for the remainder of the course.
Embedded Software An overview of they key differences between software for embedded systems and general software development.
Synchronization, Data Generation and Data Transfer A model for analyzing synchronization behaviour and performance and examples of synchronization analysis.
Buses - Data Transfer A comparison of the functional behaviour and timing behaviour of synchronous, asynchronous, and partially interlocked asynchronous.
Parallel Interfacing A detailed examination of the design of parallel interfaces.
This includes an examination of the role of the interface in matching bus timing and signaling characteristics with a device's timing and signaling characteristics.
Analog Interfacing An introduction to digital-to-analog interfacing, analog-to-digital interfacing, and sample-and-hold circuitry.
This includes a comparison of asynchronous communication techniques and synchronous techniques as well as the protocols for serial communication.

Buses - Arbitration A brief examination of alternatives for bus arbitration including a discussion of the operation and characteristics of daisy chained and non-daisy chained bus arbitration techniques.
A brief examination of direct memory access including a discussion of hardware design implications, software implications, and system performance.
Security and Ethics An overview of common security terminology and why it has become increasingly important for embedded systems.
The ethical implications of today’s embedded systems applications will also be discussed.
Other References

course_name: MATH228 - Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry (0.50)
major_name: Physics (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry Winter 2025
First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients, series solutions and special functions, the Laplace transform method.
Applications in physics and chemistry are emphasized.
Differential equations capture how some variable of interest, such as the position of a planet, changes as a function of some independent variable, such as time.
Differential equations are very widely used in the sciences because of the broad range of real-world phenomena they can describe in a mathematical framework.

In this course, students will be introduced to the universe of differential equations, including first-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, the Laplace transform method, and both exact and numerical methods for solving differential equations.
Applications in physics and chemistry will be emphasized.
understand how differential equations can be used to model physical systems,

know how to solve various classes of differential equations using numerical methods and exact methods, and

topics: Songmin Xu s83xu@uwaterloo.ca
Mastering Physics technical support: https://support.pearson.com/getsupport/s/
This is a fast-paced survey course (covering about one textbook chapter per week) introducing a wide range of topics in modern physics.

The intention is four-fold: (1) to make first-year physics more interesting; (2) to provide important, intuitive understanding of key modern physics concepts before your more mathematically rigorous courses in second year; (3) to help you decide which areas of physics you may wish to explore in more depth in upper-year electives; and (4) to have at least a brief introduction to important branches of physics you may not explore further in your degree.
Apply Newton's second law and Newton's law of universal gravitation to solve basic problems in gravitational physics.
Understand, distinguish between and correctly use the concepts of weight, weightlessness, and apparent weight.
Solve simple problems in orbital motion and apply Kepler's three laws.

Properly understand Einstein's two postulates and logically derive from them, and apply, the concepts of time dilation, length contraction, Doppler shift, velocity composition, relativity of simultaneity, and understand why special relativity works for both wave-in-ether and particle-in-vacuum models of light..
Articulate the basic, intuitive ideas of how Einstein's geometrical model of gravity works (equivalence principle and curved spacetime).
Appreciate that classical physics cannot explain the single or double slit experiments.
Understand and predict basic properties of the quantum hydrogen atom based on only the de Broglie relation and classical properties of electron orbits.
Understand the basic idea of a complex number, and in particular, a complex exponential wave, and use it to "derive" the Schrodinger equation.
Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate ionic bonds, covalent bonds, van der Waals bonds, and basic molecular spectra.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate the basic features of atomic nuclei, including nuclear binding energy, nuclear models, nuclear stability and radioactivity, nuclear reactions, nuclear fission, and nuclear fusion.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate some basic aspects of collider physics, including the concept of available energy, and an introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics.

course_name: MATH228 - Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry (0.50)
major_name: Physics (Joint Honours)
topics: Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry Winter 2025
First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients, series solutions and special functions, the Laplace transform method.
Applications in physics and chemistry are emphasized.
Differential equations capture how some variable of interest, such as the position of a planet, changes as a function of some independent variable, such as time.
Differential equations are very widely used in the sciences because of the broad range of real-world phenomena they can describe in a mathematical framework.

In this course, students will be introduced to the universe of differential equations, including first-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, the Laplace transform method, and both exact and numerical methods for solving differential equations.
Applications in physics and chemistry will be emphasized.
understand how differential equations can be used to model physical systems,
know how to classify differential equations,
know how to solve various classes of differential equations using numerical methods and exact methods, and

major_name: Physics (Joint Honours)
topics: Songmin Xu s83xu@uwaterloo.ca
Mastering Physics technical support: https://support.pearson.com/getsupport/s/
This is a fast-paced survey course (covering about one textbook chapter per week) introducing a wide range of topics in modern physics.

The intention is four-fold: (1) to make first-year physics more interesting; (2) to provide important, intuitive understanding of key modern physics concepts before your more mathematically rigorous courses in second year; (3) to help you decide which areas of physics you may wish to explore in more depth in upper-year electives; and (4) to have at least a brief introduction to important branches of physics you may not explore further in your degree.
Apply Newton's second law and Newton's law of universal gravitation to solve basic problems in gravitational physics.
Understand, distinguish between and correctly use the concepts of weight, weightlessness, and apparent weight.
Solve simple problems in orbital motion and apply Kepler's three laws.

Properly understand Einstein's two postulates and logically derive from them, and apply, the concepts of time dilation, length contraction, Doppler shift, velocity composition, relativity of simultaneity, and understand why special relativity works for both wave-in-ether and particle-in-vacuum models of light..
Articulate the basic, intuitive ideas of how Einstein's geometrical model of gravity works (equivalence principle and curved spacetime).
Appreciate that classical physics cannot explain the single or double slit experiments.
Understand and predict basic properties of the quantum hydrogen atom based on only the de Broglie relation and classical properties of electron orbits.
Understand the basic idea of a complex number, and in particular, a complex exponential wave, and use it to "derive" the Schrodinger equation.
Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate ionic bonds, covalent bonds, van der Waals bonds, and basic molecular spectra.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate the basic features of atomic nuclei, including nuclear binding energy, nuclear models, nuclear stability and radioactivity, nuclear reactions, nuclear fission, and nuclear fusion.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate some basic aspects of collider physics, including the concept of available energy, and an introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics.
Feb 24 Wave Functions Wave Functions
Mar 17 Nuclear Nuclear

major_name: Physics (Joint Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Formalism of quantum mechanics.
Identical particles.
Applications in atomic and molecular physics.
Physically predict, and mathematically model, the outcome(s) after measuring a quantum system
Understand and model the difference between a single measurement outcome and an ensemble average
Predict the time dependence of a quantum system, given its initial state and Hamiltonian
Use commutator identities to check commutation relations for operators
Write the position and momentum operators in terms of the harmonic oscillator ladder operators, and vice versa
State the commutation relations that define a set of angular momentum operators
State the spectrum (allowed eigenvalues) of the angular momentum operators 𝐽^2 and 𝐽_𝑧, in terms of quantum numbers 𝑗 and 𝑚
State the restrictions on the 𝐽^2 and 𝐽_𝑧 eigenvalues, in terms of restrictions on their associated quantum numbers 𝑗 and 𝑚
State the effect of all angular momentum operators on the joint eigenstates of 𝐽^2 and 𝐽_𝑧
Compute the matrix representations of the angular momentum operators for a given 𝑗, in the joint eigenbasis of 𝐽^2 and 𝐽_𝑧
Describe the eigenfunctions of orbital angular momentum (spherical harmonics) in the position basis
For systems with “central” potentials (those that depend only on a radial coordinate), describe the decomposition of the energy eigenfunctions into their angular and radial components
Describe the energies and eigenstates of the hydrogen atom
Describe the degeneracy of different energy eigenstates of the hydrogen atom
State two possible complete sets of mutually commuting operators (CSCOs) whose eigenstates can be used as bases to describe a set of two angular momenta
State the eigenvalues of the CSCOs used to describe a set of two angular momenta
State the selection rules for the Clebsch-Gordan coefficients that relate the coupled and uncoupled bases of a system with two angular momenta
Calculate perturbative energy shifts and wavefunction changes for nondegenerate systems
Calculate perturbative energy shifts for degenerate systems, selecting an appropriate basis for the calculation
Use the variational method to estimate the ground-state energies of simple one-dimensional problems, given a suitable trial function
State the definition of a boson and a fermion, in terms of the spin of the particles
State the symmetry properties of bosonic and fermionic wavefunctions
Exams
There will be two in-class exams given during the lecture period in our usual classroom.

HW1 - formalism and postulates - due Jan 24

HW4 - addition of angular momentum and nondegenerate perturbation theory - due Mar 12

Week 5 - Spherical harmonics and central potentials
Week 8 - Nondegenerate perturbation theory
Week 9 - Degenerate perturbation theory, fine structure, Zeeman effect
Quantum Mechanics: A Paradigms Approach, David H. McIntyre
Introduction to Quantum Mechanics, David Griffiths

major_name: Physics Minor
topics: Notice of Recording
Formalism of quantum mechanics.
Identical particles.
Applications in atomic and molecular physics.
Physically predict, and mathematically model, the outcome(s) after measuring a quantum system
Understand and model the difference between a single measurement outcome and an ensemble average
Predict the time dependence of a quantum system, given its initial state and Hamiltonian
Use commutator identities to check commutation relations for operators
Write the position and momentum operators in terms of the harmonic oscillator ladder operators, and vice versa
State the commutation relations that define a set of angular momentum operators
State the spectrum (allowed eigenvalues) of the angular momentum operators 𝐽^2 and 𝐽_𝑧, in terms of quantum numbers 𝑗 and 𝑚
State the restrictions on the 𝐽^2 and 𝐽_𝑧 eigenvalues, in terms of restrictions on their associated quantum numbers 𝑗 and 𝑚
State the effect of all angular momentum operators on the joint eigenstates of 𝐽^2 and 𝐽_𝑧
Compute the matrix representations of the angular momentum operators for a given 𝑗, in the joint eigenbasis of 𝐽^2 and 𝐽_𝑧
Describe the eigenfunctions of orbital angular momentum (spherical harmonics) in the position basis
For systems with “central” potentials (those that depend only on a radial coordinate), describe the decomposition of the energy eigenfunctions into their angular and radial components
Describe the energies and eigenstates of the hydrogen atom
Describe the degeneracy of different energy eigenstates of the hydrogen atom
State two possible complete sets of mutually commuting operators (CSCOs) whose eigenstates can be used as bases to describe a set of two angular momenta
State the eigenvalues of the CSCOs used to describe a set of two angular momenta
State the selection rules for the Clebsch-Gordan coefficients that relate the coupled and uncoupled bases of a system with two angular momenta
Calculate perturbative energy shifts and wavefunction changes for nondegenerate systems
Calculate perturbative energy shifts for degenerate systems, selecting an appropriate basis for the calculation
Use the variational method to estimate the ground-state energies of simple one-dimensional problems, given a suitable trial function
State the definition of a boson and a fermion, in terms of the spin of the particles
State the symmetry properties of bosonic and fermionic wavefunctions

course_name: MATH228 - Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry (0.50)
major_name: Physics and Astronomy (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry Winter 2025
First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients, series solutions and special functions, the Laplace transform method.
Applications in physics and chemistry are emphasized.
Differential equations capture how some variable of interest, such as the position of a planet, changes as a function of some independent variable, such as time.
Differential equations are very widely used in the sciences because of the broad range of real-world phenomena they can describe in a mathematical framework.

In this course, students will be introduced to the universe of differential equations, including first-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, the Laplace transform method, and both exact and numerical methods for solving differential equations.
Applications in physics and chemistry will be emphasized.
understand how differential equations can be used to model physical systems,
know how to classify differential equations,
know how to solve various classes of differential equations using numerical methods and exact methods, and

Unit 4 - Mechanical and Electrical Vibrations (Week 6)

Unit 8 - Systems of Differential Equations (Weeks 11 - 12)

major_name: Physics and Astronomy (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Songmin Xu s83xu@uwaterloo.ca
Mastering Physics technical support: https://support.pearson.com/getsupport/s/
This is a fast-paced survey course (covering about one textbook chapter per week) introducing a wide range of topics in modern physics.

The intention is four-fold: (1) to make first-year physics more interesting; (2) to provide important, intuitive understanding of key modern physics concepts before your more mathematically rigorous courses in second year; (3) to help you decide which areas of physics you may wish to explore in more depth in upper-year electives; and (4) to have at least a brief introduction to important branches of physics you may not explore further in your degree.
Apply Newton's second law and Newton's law of universal gravitation to solve basic problems in gravitational physics.
Understand, distinguish between and correctly use the concepts of weight, weightlessness, and apparent weight.
Solve simple problems in orbital motion and apply Kepler's three laws.

Properly understand Einstein's two postulates and logically derive from them, and apply, the concepts of time dilation, length contraction, Doppler shift, velocity composition, relativity of simultaneity, and understand why special relativity works for both wave-in-ether and particle-in-vacuum models of light..
Articulate the basic, intuitive ideas of how Einstein's geometrical model of gravity works (equivalence principle and curved spacetime).
Appreciate that classical physics cannot explain the single or double slit experiments.
Understand and predict basic properties of the quantum hydrogen atom based on only the de Broglie relation and classical properties of electron orbits.
Understand the basic idea of a complex number, and in particular, a complex exponential wave, and use it to "derive" the Schrodinger equation.
Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate ionic bonds, covalent bonds, van der Waals bonds, and basic molecular spectra.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate the basic features of atomic nuclei, including nuclear binding energy, nuclear models, nuclear stability and radioactivity, nuclear reactions, nuclear fission, and nuclear fusion.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate some basic aspects of collider physics, including the concept of available energy, and an introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics.
Feb 24 Wave Functions Wave Functions
Mar 17 Nuclear Nuclear

Topics will be chosen from linear equations, systems of linear equations, linear inequalities, functions, set theory, permutations and combinations, binomial theorem, probability theory.
The course begins with a review of operations with real numbers and fundamental algebra skills.
The solutions of polynomial equations, both linear and quadratic, in one and two variables and their graphical representation are studied.
An extension is made to linear systems with their solutions being expressed both algebraically and graphically.
To solve linear systems, matrices and the associated row reduction strategies are used.
The relationship between exponential functions and logarithmic functions is examined.
The basic properties of logarithms are introduced and used to solve logarithmic and exponential equations.
Various applications involving exponential growth and decay and logarithmic scales are presented.
Concepts in set theory and counting theory support the study of probability theory.
Perform operations with real numbers and algebraic expressions.
Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including those involving absolute value, and represent the solutions algebraically and graphically.
Solve a system of linear equations using matrix operations, introducing a free variable, or parameter as appropriate.
Solve quadratic equations in one variable.
Recognize that the solutions to a quadratic equation in two variables lie on a curve known as a parabola and analyze the properties of a parabola.
Describe the relationship between an exponential function and a logarithmic function.
Use the properties of logarithms to solve logarithmic and exponential equations, and to solve problems involving exponential growth and decay, and logarithmic scales.
Use the appropriate symbols and language in set theory to perform set operations, represent sets and subsets using Venn diagrams, and apply the counting principles for sets in real-life situations.

major_name: Pure Mathematics Minor
topics: Applied Linear Algebra 1 Winter 2025
Systems of linear equations.
Introduction to vector spaces.
We will see how to solve systems of linear equations using matrix methods before studying matrices as algebraic objects in their own right.
Next, we will learn about the fundamental concepts of span, linear independence, and basis and learn how to determine whether a set is a subspace of Rn.
After studying subspaces, we will study linear mappings, which map subspaces to subspaces.
We will discuss the geometric interpretation of these mappings and study their fundamental subspaces.
Finally, we will learn how to calculate the determinant of a matrix and use this knowledge to diagonalize square matrices.

major_name: Pure Mathematics Minor
topics: Linear Algebra 1 (Advanced Level)
Email: karigiannis@uwaterloo.ca
This course is a rigorous treatment of the theory of finite dimensional vector spaces over an arbitrary field.
We also cover the theory of determinants over an arbitrary commutative ring with identity, and some aspects of the theory of polynomials in one variable over a field.

The ultimate goal is the Primary Decomposition Theorem, which characterizes a linear operator on a finite dimensional vector space in terms of invariant subspaces annihilated by the primary factors of its minimal polynomial.
We will cover a large amount of difficult material at a fast pace.
Understand and apply the concepts of the theory of abstract vector spaces and linear operators on finite-dimensional vector spaces.
fields; systems of linear equations; matrices; row-reduced echelon form; matrix algebra; invertible matrices
vector spaces; subspaces; bases and dimension; coordinates; row equivalence
algebra of linear maps; isomorphism; representations by matrices; dual space; transpose of a linear map
commutative rings; existence and uniqueness of determinants; multilinear maps; the exterior algebra
eigenvalues; annihilating polynomials; invariant subspaces; simultaneous triangulation and diagonalization
Much (but not all) of my lectures will closely follow the first six chapters of this book:
“Linear Algebra: Second Edition” by Kenneth Hoffman and Ray Kunze; Prentice Hall, 1971.
“Linear Algebra: Fourth Edition” by Friedberg, Insel, and Spence; Prentice-Hall, 2003.

course_name: MATH104 - Introductory Calculus for Arts and Social Science (0.50)
major_name: Pure Mathematics Minor
topics: Introductory Calculus for Arts and Social Science Winter 2025
The major concepts introduced to solve problems are rate of change, optimization, growth and decay, and integration.
This course provides an introduction to the applications of differential and integral calculus in business, the behavioural sciences, and the social sciences.
A special type of limit will give rise to the derivative, the central idea in differential calculus.

The interpretation of the derivative in applications such as rates of change and optimization, where the situations can be modelled by algebraic, exponential, or logarithmic functions, will be examined.
The concepts of the antiderivative and the indefinite integral will be studied.
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus will relate the integral to the derivative.
The problem of calculating the area under a curve will lead to the definite integral, a basic concept of integral calculus.
The interpretation of the integral in various applications will be studied.
be able to interpret a limit, given the graph of a function;
evaluate the limit of a function using appropriate techniques;
determine the derivative of polynomial functions using the definition of a derivative;
determine the derivative of algebraic, exponential, and logarithmic functions using the techniques of differentiation;
apply the derivative to determining equations of tangents, graphing functions, solving rate problems, and solving optimization problems;
determine general and unique antiderivatives;
determine the indefinite integral of a function using the techniques of integration;
determine definite integrals; and

The goal of this course is to further expand your knowledge of calculus and its applications for one-variable functions.

First, we will explore areas under curves and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, integration techniques, and applications of integration including finding the area between two curves, volumes of solids of revolution, and the average value of a function.
We will study how to solve separable differential equations and linear differential equations as well as their applications to population growth and Newton's Law of Cooling.

major_name: Science (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.

course_name: MATH103 - Introductory Algebra for Arts and Social Science (0.50)
major_name: Science (Joint Honours with Arts Major)
topics: Notice of Recording
Introductory Algebra for Arts and Social Science Winter 2025
Email: jen.nelson@uwaterloo.ca
Topics will be chosen from linear equations, systems of linear equations, linear inequalities, functions, set theory, permutations and combinations, binomial theorem, probability theory.
The course begins with a review of operations with real numbers and fundamental algebra skills.
The solutions of polynomial equations, both linear and quadratic, in one and two variables and their graphical representation are studied.
An extension is made to linear systems with their solutions being expressed both algebraically and graphically.
To solve linear systems, matrices and the associated row reduction strategies are used.
The relationship between exponential functions and logarithmic functions is examined.
The basic properties of logarithms are introduced and used to solve logarithmic and exponential equations.
Various applications involving exponential growth and decay and logarithmic scales are presented.
Concepts in set theory and counting theory support the study of probability theory.
Perform operations with real numbers and algebraic expressions.
Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including those involving absolute value, and represent the solutions algebraically and graphically.
Solve a system of linear equations using matrix operations, introducing a free variable, or parameter as appropriate.
Solve quadratic equations in one variable.
Recognize that the solutions to a quadratic equation in two variables lie on a curve known as a parabola and analyze the properties of a parabola.
Describe the relationship between an exponential function and a logarithmic function.
Use the properties of logarithms to solve logarithmic and exponential equations, and to solve problems involving exponential growth and decay, and logarithmic scales.
Use the appropriate symbols and language in set theory to perform set operations, represent sets and subsets using Venn diagrams, and apply the counting principles for sets in real-life situations.

major_name: Science and Aviation (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.

This workshop addresses concepts of technology development and related marketing aspects that undertake an analysis of a firm's existence, its physical and/or social media presence, and customer feedback.
Students work in collaborative teams to tackle case studies and class exercises.
This involves conducting a PESTLE and SWOT analysis, market planning, information retrieval strategies, scientific business forecasting, competitive intelligence, and product development.
In this introductory Business Development Workshop, you will learn how to go about understanding and generating business development ideas.
Through the development of a full-fledged marketing plan for your product or service you will participate in the planning and preparation of your own Business Development Strategy.
You will consider the overall impact this change will have on your development as a Science and Business student.
Remember that every time you promote your product the first question asked is do you have a strategy?
This course will be the first step in developing a strategic plan.

Current real-world issues and problems in the strategic management of start-ups and scientific/technology companies are addressed, based on the use of publicly available information including research findings.

Ongoing identification and implementation of new processes, service, products and/or product designs are important for growth and business viability in both established traditional companies, and entrepreneurial start-up firms.
Strategic planning and focused implementation of strategic decisions are necessary to sustain corporate growth.

The theory of rates of interest and discount; annuities and sinking funds with practical applications to mortgage and bond questions.
This course provides foundational tools for understanding key financial concepts, such as interest rates, annuities, loans, and bonds.

The principles introduced are essential for performing calculations related to everyday financial matters, like determining mortgage payments or valuing investments, and they play a key role in sectors like banking, insurance, and real estate.

By the end of the course, you will have a strong grasp of the mathematical techniques used to approach real-world financial problems, laying a foundation for further study and practical applications in finance and actuarial science.

major_name: Human-Computer Interaction Specialization
topics: Human-Computer Interaction Fall 2024
LEC - Monday 10-11:30am DC 1350
An introduction to the fundamental theories, methods, and research in the design and evaluation of novel computational artifacts designed to meet real-world human needs.
Through lectures and design activities, students work in teams of 5 to design a solution for a real-world problem.
The end result of the team project is a high-fidelity interactive prototype of a mobile application, targeted at solving a particular real-world problem.
Identify the primary luminaries in Interactive Design and HCI
Identify your target users
Design studies to understand your users and their needs within a sociocultural context
Create user data-driven designs and prototypes of different levels of fidelity
Design studies to evaluate designs during different stages of the project
Properly gather and analyze qualitative and quantitative data from semi-structured interviews, paper prototype evaluation, heuristic evaluations and cognitive walkthrough
Discover a variety of HCI research methodologies
Add a high-quality design of an interesting product to your design portfolio
The success of a team project depends critically on each student being a responsible member of the team, i.e., showing up and participating.
Special consideration can be made for a few exceptions (e.g., academic travel, illnesses and family emergencies).

major_name: Human-Computer Interaction Specialization
topics: Engineering and Peace Fall 2024
Office Hours: Online or in-person meetings can be booked via Calendly between 8:30 AM – 4:30 PM on weekdays

This course is built on the conviction that the kinds of problems engineers seek to address, and the ways they seek to address them, should matter for anyone interested in advancing peace in the world.
Topics include historical connections between the discipline of engineering and warfare, understanding the engineering method and mindset, and technological frontiers for peacebuilding.
Augment their approach to analyzing and solving problems with insights from both engineering and peacebuilding theory and practice; and
Identify opportunities to apply their expertise and passions to make a meaningful social impact

The intention is four-fold: (1) to make first-year physics more interesting; (2) to provide important, intuitive understanding of key modern physics concepts before your more mathematically rigorous courses in second year; (3) to help you decide which areas of physics you may wish to explore in more depth in upper-year electives; and (4) to have at least a brief introduction to important branches of physics you may not explore further in your degree.
Apply Newton's second law and Newton's law of universal gravitation to solve basic problems in gravitational physics.
Understand, distinguish between and correctly use the concepts of weight, weightlessness, and apparent weight.
Solve simple problems in orbital motion and apply Kepler's three laws.

Properly understand Einstein's two postulates and logically derive from them, and apply, the concepts of time dilation, length contraction, Doppler shift, velocity composition, relativity of simultaneity, and understand why special relativity works for both wave-in-ether and particle-in-vacuum models of light..
Articulate the basic, intuitive ideas of how Einstein's geometrical model of gravity works (equivalence principle and curved spacetime).
Appreciate that classical physics cannot explain the single or double slit experiments.
Understand and predict basic properties of the quantum hydrogen atom based on only the de Broglie relation and classical properties of electron orbits.
Understand the basic idea of a complex number, and in particular, a complex exponential wave, and use it to "derive" the Schrodinger equation.
Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate ionic bonds, covalent bonds, van der Waals bonds, and basic molecular spectra.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate the basic features of atomic nuclei, including nuclear binding energy, nuclear models, nuclear stability and radioactivity, nuclear reactions, nuclear fission, and nuclear fusion.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate some basic aspects of collider physics, including the concept of available energy, and an introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics.
Feb 24 Wave Functions Wave Functions
Mar 17 Nuclear Nuclear

course_name: CS489 - Advanced Topics in Computer Science (0.50)
major_name: Software Engineering (Bachelor of Software Engineering - Honours)
topics: Instructor: Stacey Watson
It examines the software development life cycle and teaches what developers can do in each step to make their software more secure.

Explain core security concepts (including the CIA triad, authentication, and authorization) and analyze the technical, psychological, and economic factors that contribute to security vulnerabilities in software systems.

Apply secure design principles throughout the software development lifecycle, including threat modelling, architectural reviews, and cryptographic techniques, to create systems that are secure by design rather than through retrofitting.

Identify, analyze, and mitigate common implementation-level vulnerabilities, including those related to access control, resource management, calculation errors, and improper input neutralization (such as SQL injection and XSS attacks).

Implement a comprehensive security testing strategy that combines multiple approaches (static analysis, runtime testing, fuzzing, and security scorecards) to effectively identify and validate security vulnerabilities throughout the development process.

Evaluate and appropriately utilize modern development tools, including AI code generation tools, while understanding their security implications and implementing necessary safeguards to ensure the security of the resulting software.
Security Concepts and the Vulnerability Landscape
Challenges and Best Practices in Secure Development

Prof. Kerstin Dautenhahn:
kerstin.dautenhahn@uwaterloo.ca
ECE 750:
View requirements for ECE 750
View requirements for ECE 493
The course will provide an introduction to the research field of social robotics, with a particular human-centered perspective.

Robots that can interact socially in an effective and acceptable manner with people have become increasingly important for applications ranging from robot-assisted therapy for people with special needs, robotic assistants for older people and care home residents, robots as tools in education or robotic co-workers for a new generation of  industrial robot that emphasize human-machine collaboration and communication.

Students will gain an understanding of the concepts and theories underlying social robotics, as well as research methodologies and techniques to realize socially intelligent robots and design, plan and evaluate human-robot interaction experiments.
Understand concepts and theories underlying social robotics
Apply research methodologies and techniques to realize socially intelligent robots
Design, plan, and evaluate human-robot interaction experiments
Demonstrate scientific writing and presentation skills
Explain how psychology and social sciences can inform the engineering of social robots
Understand basic principles of sensors, actuators and multi-model interaction and communication for social robots
Explain examples of robot computational architectures used in human-robot interaction
Definitions of social robots and requirements of robots’ social skill and their relevance to robotics and Artificial Intelligence in real-world applications
The role of affective expressions of social robots and modelling emotions to facilitate human-robot engagement
Evaluating usability, user experience and acceptance of social robots
Guidelines of how to write up social robotics research for a scientific publication
Overview of cognitive architectures for socially intelligent robots
Featuring interdisciplinary research in social robotics based on research from other fields, e.g. from (developmental) psychology, ethology or primatology
Roles of social robots in human society and their potential impact on society and wellbeing
Selected examples of applications of social robots e.g. in care, therapy, education, rehabilitation and co-worker scenarios will be discussed throughout the course
Ethical, safety and privacy issues as relevant to social robotics will be discussed throughout the course
Course Grading for Graduate Students:

20% Individual discussion paper: Students will reflect on work in Science Fiction involving the concepts of social and intelligent robots, and reflect on the relevance to today’s robotics technology in robotics and Artificial Intelligence.
Students can choose the work and discuss the selection with the instructor.

Students are required to write a report that motivates, describes and discusses those behaviours in light of the state of the art literature, and describe an experimental design for a human-robot interaction experiment where those behaviours could be tested and analyzed.

Specifically, students’ reports will be evaluated based on a) the literature review demonstrating the level of knowledge in this domain, b) the relevance of the identified research questions and hypotheses, c) the depth of the proposed research program, d) the range, complexity and quality of the implemented and documented robot behaviours, e) the detailed description of the methodology used to carry out and analyze this program of work, f) the user study conducted and how results are presented and analysed, and finally, g) a critical evaluation of possible limitations of the expected outcomes and backup plans in order to address  possible delays and technical difficulties encountered during the implementation of the work.
Note, those skills can also be applied to related fields of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI), Human Factors etc.

course_name: CO485 - The Mathematics of Public-Key Cryptography (0.50)
major_name: Software Engineering (Bachelor of Software Engineering - Honours)
topics: The Mathematics of Public-Key Cryptography Fall 2024
An in-depth study of public-key cryptography.
Public-key encryption, digital signatures, key establishment, elliptic curve cryptography, post-quantum cryptography.

An in-depth study of public-key cryptography, including: number-theoretic problems - prime generation, integer factorization, discrete logarithms; public-key encryption; digital signatures; key establishment; elliptic curve cryptography; post-quantum cryptography; and security proofs.
An in-depth study of public-key cryptography and number-theoretic problems related to the efficient and secure use of public-key cryptographic schemes.
Algorithmic number theory: Primality testing, integer factorization problem, discrete logarithm problem, elliptic curve discrete logarithm problem.
Additional topics: Pairing-based cryptography, post-quantum cryptography.
An Introduction to Mathematical Cryptography (2nd ed.), Hoffstein, Pipher, and Silverman.
The quizzes are intended to reinforce basic concepts that are, in some sense, "too easy" to put in an assignment (e.g., definitions, simple calculations).

major_name: Statistics (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Mathematical Statistics Winter 2025
This course provides a mathematically rigorous treatment for topics covered in STAT230 and 231, and to make essential extensions to the multivariate case.

Topics covered include independence of random variables, conditional expectation and the determination of the distribution of functions of random variables using the cumulative distribution method, change of variable and moment generating functions.
Asymptotic properties of the maximum likelihood estimator are examined and used to construct confidence intervals or regions.

topics: Introduction to Computational Mathematics Winter 2025
A rigorous introduction to the field of computational mathematics.
The focus is on the interplay between continuous models and their solution via discrete processes.
Topics include pitfalls in computation, solution of linear systems, interpolation, discrete Fourier transforms, and numerical integration.

Analyze problems in terms of conditioning, and algorithms in terms of stability

Apply these algorithms to solve problems from various domains

Knowledge Base - Demonstrated competence in university level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the program.
Problem Analysis - An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

Investigation - An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.

Design - An ability to design solutions for complex, open-ended engineering problems and to design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate attention to health and safety risks, applicable standards, and economic, environmental, cultural and societal considerations.
Communication Skills - An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.

Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking and listening, and the ability to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.
Professionalism - An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.
Impact of Engineering - An ability to analyze social and environmental aspects of engineering activities.

Such ability includes an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society, the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.

Lifelong Learning - An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world in ways sufficient to maintain their competence and to allow them to contribute to the advancement of knowledge.

Introduction to the basic theory and principles of mechanics of static systems.
Applications of mechanical principles to musculoskeletal systems will be presented.
Basic concepts of mechanics, vectors.
Analysis of trusses and frames.
Distributed forces, centroids, and moments of inertia.
Engineering mechanics involves the combination of physics and mathematics to develop models of physical world and solve problems in the physical world.
In this course, you will acquire knowledge of the theory and principles of engineering mechanics of static systems and become proficient in problem solving in this area.

You will acquire skills in analysing a problem, developing a plan to solve the problem including creating a mechanics-based model of the system, and proceeding to solve the problem with full understanding of the fundamentals and approach, not by memorization.
Examples of the application of statics to mechanics of materials and musculoskeletal biomechanics will be discussed.
A) Conduct vector mathematics operations (addition, subtraction, vector products)
B) Calculate moments, centres of mass, and forces for particular structures.
C) Describe position, forces, and moments in terms of vector in appropriate reference frames in two and three dimensions.
E) Simplify systems of forces and moments to equivalent systems.
F) Draw complete free-body diagrams and write appropriate equilibrium equations from the free-body diagram, including the support reactions on a structure.
H) Determine the internal forces in a structure.
a) Demonstrate understanding of concepts in mathematics A, B, C  All
b) Demonstrate understanding of concepts in natural science B, C, D, E, F, G, H  All
c) Demonstrate understanding of engineering fundamentals F, G, H, I  All
a) Generate appropriate documentation to communicate within the profession and to society at large F, I, J  All

topics: Human-Computer Interaction Fall 2024
This course is designed to provide in-depth exposure to the concepts of human-computer interaction and methods of interactive information system design.

The course will focus on techniques for building information systems that meet human needs and capabilities by following a system development lifecycle: user requirements analysis, information and interaction design, prototyping and evaluation.

course_name: MTE325 - Microprocessor Systems and Interfacing for Mechatronics Engineering (0.50)
major_name: Systems Design Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Microprocessor Systems and Interfacing for Mechatronics Engineering Winter 2025
book a meeting
Synchronization and data flow; interfacing to sensors and actuators;
parallel, serial, and analog interfacing; buses; direct memory access (DMA); interfacing considerations; privacy and security considerations.
View requirements for MTE 325
Summarize the flow of data between software and hardware elements in an embedded system
Describe the trade-offs between implementation alternatives for both hardware and software
Outline the ethical implications of embedded system design choices
Use industry-standard tools to implement and debug embedded systems
Design an embedded system to perform a given task
Projects provide students with an opportunity to explore selected concepts in a real-world context.
Lectures and tutorials are held in person and attendance is expected at all sessions for learning and skill development.
Jan 20th and Jan 22nd  Lab 1 – Introduction and setup (watch Learn for signup instructions closer to)
Lab 2 – Synchronization Techniques
Course Introduction An introduction to the teaching team, course expectations, deliverables, marking scheme, and a very brief introduction to interfacing concepts.
Embedded Systems A review of fundamentals of embedded systems and the terminology associated with embedded systems.
Embedded Design Model An introduction to the embedded design model used to develop a system for the remainder of the course.
Embedded Software An overview of they key differences between software for embedded systems and general software development.
Synchronization, Data Generation and Data Transfer A model for analyzing synchronization behaviour and performance and examples of synchronization analysis.
Buses - Data Transfer A comparison of the functional behaviour and timing behaviour of synchronous, asynchronous, and partially interlocked asynchronous.
Parallel Interfacing A detailed examination of the design of parallel interfaces.
This includes an examination of the role of the interface in matching bus timing and signaling characteristics with a device's timing and signaling characteristics.
Analog Interfacing An introduction to digital-to-analog interfacing, analog-to-digital interfacing, and sample-and-hold circuitry.
This includes a comparison of asynchronous communication techniques and synchronous techniques as well as the protocols for serial communication.

Buses - Arbitration A brief examination of alternatives for bus arbitration including a discussion of the operation and characteristics of daisy chained and non-daisy chained bus arbitration techniques.
A brief examination of direct memory access including a discussion of hardware design implications, software implications, and system performance.
Security and Ethics An overview of common security terminology and why it has become increasingly important for embedded systems.
The ethical implications of today’s embedded systems applications will also be discussed.
Other References

Your project average includes your grades for all project demonstrations and submissions.
Students will need to make design decisions and use the resources that are typically available for a particular embedded system application.

The purpose of this project is to provide practice with applications of course concepts and experience tackling an open-ended interfacing problem in preparation for their 3rd and 4th year design projects.

major_name: Systems Design Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Planning for Design of a Sustainable Hospital System Winter 2025
lisa.aultman-hall@uwaterloo.ca
This course deals with selected topics at the undergraduate level in environmental and societal systems, mechatronics and physical systems, or human factors and ergonomics.
Three frameworks or tools ground the course in systems design engineering:
systems thinking (with mapping); and
access and transportation;
green energy; or
Co-laboratory definitions of sustainability and hospital systems;
Summaries and reviews of hospital sustainability literature;
Short design reports of alternative hospital site designs; and
Identify and conceptualize the role of a hospital system in a community and region.
Appreciate the complexity of defining sustainability for a hospital, a complex social technical system.
Clearly define the hospital site as a design problem with a sustainability-based objective.
Identify multiple conceptual design alternatives for the Waterloo hospital site and evaluate the extent to which each meets sustainability goals and objectives using metrics.
Use systems thinking to frame a complex problem and communicate the elements of a system using mapping.
Work effectively in a collaborative team environment by co-developing definitions, documents, and system representations of a complex system.
